{
"title": "The Lean Startup",
"author": "Eric Ries",
"category": "Foundational Startup",
"tags": ["lean", "MVP", "experimentation", "validated learning", "build measure learn"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "Startups are learning machines. The primary goal is validated learning about customers and the business model, achieved through fast experiments rather than long planning cycles.",
"problem_statement": "Founders waste years building products that nobody wants because they rely on assumptions, long development cycles, and vanity metrics.",
"target_audience": "Early stage founders, product leaders, and innovation teams who operate under high uncertainty.",
"promised_transformation": "The reader learns to systematically test assumptions, build minimum viable products, measure real behavior, and decide whether to pivot or persevere.",
"key_ideas": [
"Startups exist to learn how to build a sustainable business.",
"Validated learning is the unit of progress in a startup.",
"The Build Measure Learn feedback loop enables fast iteration.",
"MVPs help test assumptions with minimal effort.",
"Innovation accounting replaces vanity metrics with actionable ones.",
"Pivot or persevere decisions should be made based on learning, not ego.",
"Small batch work and continuous deployment support fast learning."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "Build Measure Learn Feedback Loop",
"type": "framework",
"description": "A continuous loop where startups build a product experiment, measure customer reactions, and learn whether their assumptions are correct.",
"components": [
"Build: create the simplest experiment or MVP.",
"Measure: collect data on real customer behavior.",
"Learn: decide what the data implies for assumptions.",
"Repeat: refine the product or change direction."
],
"when_it_applies": "Anytime a team is making decisions under uncertainty about product features, market segments, or business models.",
"limitations": "If measurement is poor, learning will be distorted. Some strategic decisions require longer time horizons."
},
{
"name": "Minimum Viable Product (MVP)",
"type": "framework",
"description": "The simplest version of a product that allows you to start the learning process with the least amount of effort.",
"components": [
"Core value hypothesis.",
"Simplest manifestation of that value.",
"Real customers and real behavior.",
"Clear success criteria."
],
"when_it_applies": "Before investing in full product development or significant scaling.",
"limitations": "If executed poorly, an MVP can harm brand perception or give misleading data if not targeted correctly."
},
{
"name": "Validated Learning",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Learning that is confirmed by data from real customer behavior rather than opinions, focus groups, or internal debates.",
"components": [
"Clear hypothesis.",
"Experiment design.",
"Actionable metrics.",
"Interpretation and decision."
],
"when_it_applies": "Every time the team is unsure whether an assumption in their model is true.",
"limitations": "Can be slow if experiments are large. Experiments can be biased or poorly designed."
},
{
"name": "Pivot or Persevere",
"type": "framework",
"description": "A structured decision point where the startup chooses to change direction or continue based on what it has learned.",
"components": [
"Assessment of current metrics and learning.",
"List of key assumptions that remain unvalidated.",
"Alternative strategic directions (pivots).",
"Commitment to a new hypothesis or to continuing."
],
"when_it_applies": "After several iterations when growth is stagnant or metrics are not improving meaningfully.",
"limitations": "Emotional attachment and sunk cost bias can distort the decision."
},
{
"name": "Innovation Accounting",
"type": "framework",
"description": "A method to measure progress when traditional financial metrics are not yet meaningful, by tracking validated learning and cohort behavior.",
"components": [
"Baseline: current customer behavior and metrics.",
"Tuning: experiments to improve those metrics.",
"Target: expected improvement from new experiments.",
"Cohort based tracking."
],
"when_it_applies": "Pre revenue or early revenue stages where qualitative and cohort metrics matter more than top line growth.",
"limitations": "Requires discipline and good instrumentation. Can be complex to set up for non technical teams."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Designing Your First MVP",
"related_framework": "Minimum Viable Product (MVP)",
"use_case": "Founders at idea stage or pre launch wanting to test demand and value quickly.",
"steps": [
"Write down your core value hypothesis: what change do you believe your product creates for the user.",
"Identify the riskiest assumption that must be true for your startup to work, such as willingness to pay, frequency of use, or real problem severity.",
"Brainstorm the simplest way to test that assumption with real users. This might be a landing page, manual service, prototype, or concierge version.",
"Define clear success metrics for the experiment, for example, sign up rate, pre orders, meetings booked, or retention over a short period.",
"Recruit a small group of target users and run the MVP experiment.",
"Collect both quantitative data and qualitative feedback.",
"Decide what you learned and what experiment comes next."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"A landing page with a clear offer and waitlist to test interest before building the product.",
"A manual WhatsApp based service to test demand for a future app.",
"A Figma prototype to test navigation and core flows before coding."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Overbuilding the MVP into a full product.",
"Testing with the wrong audience.",
"Not defining success criteria before the experiment.",
"Ignoring negative feedback by rationalizing it away."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Conversion rate on the primary action for the MVP.",
"Cost or effort per validated learning cycle.",
"Follow through behavior such as repeated usage or engagement."
]
},
{
"name": "Running Lean Experiments Using Build Measure Learn",
"related_framework": "Build Measure Learn Feedback Loop",
"use_case": "Teams that want a repeatable approach for experimentation across product and GTM.",
"steps": [
"Create a backlog of assumptions that matter for your business model, such as problem worth solving, solution fit, pricing, channels, and messaging.",
"For each assumption, define a simple testable hypothesis.",
"Design the smallest possible experiment that can generate evidence for or against the hypothesis.",
"Implement the experiment in a short time frame, ideally days or weeks, not months.",
"Instrument the experiment with meaningful metrics rather than vanity metrics.",
"Run the experiment and collect results.",
"Hold a learning review to decide what the results mean and what to test next."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Testing two value propositions on ads that drive to the same product page.",
"Offering different price points to small cohorts to test price sensitivity.",
"Testing different onboarding flows to see the effect on activation."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Running experiments without hypotheses or learning goals.",
"Stopping experiments too early before patterns emerge.",
"Drawing strong conclusions from very small samples.",
"Changing multiple variables at once and not knowing what caused the effect."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Experiment cycle time.",
"Number of experiments run per month.",
"Rate of validated vs invalidated hypotheses.",
"Improvement in key funnel metrics over time."
]
},
{
"name": "Making a Pivot or Persevere Decision",
"related_framework": "Pivot or Persevere",
"use_case": "A team has run several experiments, growth is flat, and there is confusion about whether to keep pushing or change direction.",
"steps": [
"Collect your last several months of key metrics, including acquisition, activation, retention, and revenue if relevant.",
"List the main experiments you have run and what you learned from each.",
"Identify which core assumptions have been validated and which remain unproven or disproved.",
"Brainstorm pivot options such as changing target customer segment, value proposition, channel, or revenue model.",
"For each pivot option, outline a new core hypothesis and a first experiment.",
"Decide whether the current trajectory has a realistic path to meaningful improvement or whether a pivot option offers a higher expected value.",
"Commit as a team to either persevere with clear new experiments or to pivot and treat it as a new startup phase."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Pivoting from a B2C habit tracking app to a B2B employee wellness product after seeing better engagement in corporate pilots.",
"Pivoting from a horizontal tool to a niche vertical where early users showed strong enthusiasm."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Delaying the decision for too long and slowly burning cash.",
"Pivoting too frequently, never giving an approach enough time.",
"Choosing a pivot driven by excitement rather than evidence."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Pre and post pivot changes in core metrics.",
"Runway remaining and burn rate.",
"Speed and clarity of decision making around pivots."
]
}
]
}

{
"title": "The Hard Thing About Hard Things",
"author": "Ben Horowitz",
"category": "Foundational Startup",
"tags": ["leadership", "CEO decisions", "startups", "culture", "crisis management"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "The hardest part of building a company is managing through chaos, uncertainty, and pain. There are no easy formulas. Leaders must make tough, often ugly decisions while staying honest, resilient, and responsible for their people.",
"problem_statement": "Most startup advice focuses on strategy and tactics in ideal conditions. Founders are unprepared for layoffs, near death experiences, brutal market turns, and psychological pressure.",
"target_audience": "Founders, CEOs, and senior leaders in high growth or high stress environments.",
"promised_transformation": "The reader gains a realistic view of what it takes to lead a company through hard times and learns practical approaches to layoffs, demotions, communication, and decision making under pressure.",
"key_ideas": [
"There is no recipe for the hard things. Leaders must make judgment calls with incomplete information.",
"The CEO job is lonely and emotionally demanding. Managing your own psychology is crucial.",
"Telling things as they are builds trust and alignment, even when the news is bad.",
"Designing and maintaining culture is a core responsibility, not a side project.",
"Sometimes you must choose between bad options, such as layoffs or running out of cash.",
"You should train and evaluate people for the job they need to do, not just loyalty.",
"Struggle is normal, and enduring it is part of the founder journey."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "Peacetime CEO vs Wartime CEO",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Two different modes of leadership. Peacetime focuses on expansion, optimization, and culture building. Wartime focuses on survival, decisive action, and clear command when the company is under existential threat.",
"components": [
"Peacetime: emphasize collaboration, process, and long term projects.",
"Wartime: emphasize speed, focus, and direct control.",
"Context: market conditions, competitive threats, runway.",
"Leader behavior: communication style, decision rights, risk appetite."
],
"when_it_applies": "When a company is facing existential risk, major competition, or severe resource constraints.",
"limitations": "Leaders can over dramatize situations and stay in wartime mode longer than necessary, which can burn people out."
},
{
"name": "Managing Your Own Psychology",
"type": "principle",
"description": "The CEO's emotional state strongly influences the entire company. Founders must manage fear, anxiety, and self doubt in order to make good decisions and lead effectively.",
"components": [
"Awareness of your emotional state.",
"Support system and mentors.",
"Separating facts from stories in your head.",
"Rituals and practices to stay grounded."
],
"when_it_applies": "Always, but especially during crises, layoffs, and failures.",
"limitations": "Some psychological challenges may require professional help beyond self management."
},
{
"name": "Good vs Bad Product CEO",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Horowitz contrasts leaders who deeply understand the product and customers with leaders who delegate product thinking entirely.",
"components": [
"Understanding the user and use cases.",
"Participating in product reviews.",
"Balancing visionary direction with team autonomy.",
"Using product quality as a key leadership lever."
],
"when_it_applies": "Especially in product led companies where differentiation is built on product excellence.",
"limitations": "A CEO cannot micro manage product details at scale, but must still have strong product intuition."
},
{
"name": "Communicating Bad News",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Being honest and direct with the team about challenges builds trust, even when the message is hard.",
"components": [
"Explain the situation clearly.",
"Own your role in it.",
"Explain the options and the decision made.",
"Show empathy and respect for those affected.",
"Outline the path forward."
],
"when_it_applies": "During layoffs, missed targets, lost deals, or strategic setbacks.",
"limitations": "Oversharing raw fears without framing can create panic. The message needs both honesty and direction."
},
{
"name": "Hiring and Firing for the Company You Need",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Hiring should be done based on the role and skills needed at the current and next stage, not based solely on loyalty. Sometimes loyal early employees are no longer the right fit.",
"components": [
"Define the role and outcomes clearly.",
"Assess skills and experience against those outcomes.",
"Be honest about gaps and whether they can be coached.",
"Move people out of roles when they cannot meet the demands."
],
"when_it_applies": "Scaling phases where the complexity of the business increases.",
"limitations": "These decisions are emotionally hard and can damage trust if not communicated and executed respectfully."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Switching Into Wartime CEO Mode",
"related_framework": "Peacetime CEO vs Wartime CEO",
"use_case": "Runway is short, growth has stalled, or a competitor is threatening your core business.",
"steps": [
"Assess whether you truly face an existential threat or if this is a normal fluctuation.",
"If the threat is real, declare clearly to your leadership team that you are entering wartime mode and explain why.",
"Narrow company priorities to a very small number of critical objectives related to survival and core competitiveness.",
"Re evaluate all projects and stop or postpone everything that does not drive the critical objectives.",
"Increase the cadence and directness of communication. Make decisions faster and accept that some will be imperfect.",
"Protect the core team and resources needed to execute in this mode.",
"Review regularly whether conditions have changed enough to move back toward peacetime behaviors."

"examples_for_startups": [

"A startup facing an aggressive competitor doubling down on its strongest product and niche rather than expanding."

"Using wartime as an excuse for poor behavior or lack of transparency.",
"Overreacting to smaller problems as if they are existential threats."

"Team engagement and retention among key players."

},
{
"name": "Running Humane but Decisive Layoffs",
"related_framework": "Communicating Bad News",
"use_case": "The company must reduce headcount to survive or reach profitability.",
"steps": [

"Design the new org structure first, then determine which roles are essential.",
"Plan a single decisive layoff rather than many smaller ones, if possible, to avoid ongoing fear.",
"Prepare clear written and spoken communication that explains why this is happening, how decisions were made, and what support will be provided.",
"Deliver the news with empathy and respect to affected individuals, ideally in person or via personal calls.",
"Provide as much support as you reasonably can: severance, references, introductions.",
"Communicate transparently with the remaining team about what happened and what the plan is going forward."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"A startup reducing 30 percent of staff once, with clear messaging and runway extension, instead of small monthly cuts.",
"Founders personally helping affected employees with introductions to other companies."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Cutting too little and needing to do additional layoffs soon after.",
"Blaming external factors entirely and not taking any responsibility.",
"Treating people transactionally and damaging reputation and culture long term."

"metrics_to_track": [

"Remaining team morale and trust as measured in candid conversations or surveys.",
"Legal and reputational issues avoided by handling the process properly."
]
},
{
"name": "Managing Your CEO Psychology",
"related_framework": "Managing Your Own Psychology",
"use_case": "Founder or CEO feels overwhelmed, anxious, or isolated and this is beginning to affect decisions.",
"steps": [
"Name the main fears or worries explicitly in writing to reduce their power.",
"Separate what is in your control from what is not and focus attention on controllable actions.",
"Build a small circle of trusted peers, mentors, or coaches you can speak with honestly.",
"Create non negotiable personal routines that support mental health, such as sleep, exercise, and time with loved ones.",
"Limit exposure to constant negative stimuli, such as obsessively checking metrics or social media.",
"Schedule regular reflection time for strategic thinking rather than living only in reactive mode.",
"Acknowledge that struggle is normal in this role and that needing support is not a weakness."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"A founder starting a weekly call with another founder to share the real state of their businesses.",
"Blocking out two mornings a week for deep work and thinking instead of endless meetings."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Pretending everything is fine and bottling up stress until it explodes.",
"Using work as an escape and burning out completely.",
"Making large strategic decisions from a place of panic or exhaustion."
],
"metrics_to_track": [

"Consistency of basic health routines.",
"Quality of decisions and clarity of thinking, reflected in fewer reactive reversals."

}
]

"Execution: sprints, rituals, ownership.",
"Metrics: KPIs, guardrails, health metrics.",
"Cross-functional alignment: PM, eng, design, sales, marketing, support."
],
"when_it_applies": "50+ employees or multi-team product organizations.",
"limitations": "Too much structure can slow innovation if applied prematurely."
},
{
"name": "Process as a Speed Enabler",
"type": "principle",
"description": "The right point to introduce process is when a lack of process slows the team down, not before.",
"components": [
"Lightweight planning cycles.",
"Decision-making frameworks.",
"Consistent review cadences.",
"Documentation of repeatable processes."
],
"when_it_applies": "When teams begin stepping on each other’s work or misalign frequently.",
"limitations": "Over-processing leads to bureaucracy."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Hiring Your First Executive Team",
"related_framework": "Executive Hiring Framework",
"use_case": "A founder is overwhelmed and needs to scale leadership capacity.",
"steps": [

"Create a target profile for each exec (must-have vs nice-to-have).",
"Source candidates primarily through trusted networks.",

"Conduct deep, back-channel references from former reports and managers.",
"Align incentives and equity to expected scope and impact.",
"Set clear 30/60/90-day success metrics for onboarding."

"examples_for_startups": [

"Hiring a VP of Engineering when coordination across squads becomes complex."
],
"failure_modes": [

"Not conducting rigorous references.",
"Misaligned expectations around stage fit."
],
"metrics_to_track": [

"Team performance under new leadership.",
"Achievement of 90-day and 180-day goals."
]
},
{
"name": "Scaling Org Structure Effectively",
"related_framework": "Org Design Principles",
"use_case": "Founder needs to reduce chaos and improve coordination.",
"steps": [

"examples_for_startups": [

"failure_modes": [

]
},
{

"examples_for_startups": [

"Centralized product review with CEO every two weeks."
],
"failure_modes": [

"Unclear decision rights.",
"Roadmaps becoming static instead of adaptive."

"metrics_to_track": [

}

{
"title": "The Mom Test",
"author": "Rob Fitzpatrick",
"category": "Customer Development",
"tags": ["customer interviews", "validation", "product discovery", "early stage"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "Most founders collect false positives during customer conversations because they ask leading, biased, or hypothetical questions. Good customer conversations focus on the customer’s life—not the founder’s idea.",
"problem_statement": "Founders receive polite lies, over-optimistic feedback, and misleading enthusiasm that leads them to build products nobody wants.",
"target_audience": "Early stage founders, product teams, and anyone conducting customer interviews.",
"promised_transformation": "A practical set of rules to run unbiased customer conversations that reveal real problems, willingness to pay, and actual behavior.",
"key_ideas": [
"Don't talk about your idea; talk about the customer’s life.",
"Ask about past behaviors, not opinions or hypotheticals.",
"Good questions cannot be answered with polite lies.",
"Learning happens when customers talk about their real problems.",
"Commitments and actions matter more than compliments.",
"Avoid being pitched solutions by customers; extract the underlying problem.",
"Customer conversations are a skill and can be practiced."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "The Mom Test Rules",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Three core rules that ensure customer conversations stay grounded in reality and are immune to polite lies.",
"components": [
"Talk about their life instead of your idea.",
"Ask about specifics in the past instead of opinions about the future.",
"Talk less and listen more."
],
"when_it_applies": "Any customer interview before product-market fit.",
"limitations": "Not a replacement for quantitative validation; works best for early discovery."
},
{
"name": "Good Questions vs Bad Questions",
"type": "model",
"description": "Bad questions give you compliments; good questions give you data.",
"components": [
"Bad: 'Would you use this?', 'Do you like the idea?', 'How much would you pay?'",
"Good: 'Tell me about the last time this happened.', 'How do you solve it today?', 'What have you tried?'"
],
"when_it_applies": "First 10–50 user interviews.",
"limitations": "Requires discipline to avoid pitching."
},
{
"name": "Three Types of Data in Customer Conversations",
"type": "definition",
"description": "Signals that indicate real customer need.",
"components": [
"Compliments (dangerous: meaningless).",
"Fluff and opinions (dangerous unless tied to behavior).",
"Commitments and advancements (valuable: real signal)."
],
"when_it_applies": "Interview synthesis and decision-making.",
"limitations": "Commitments can still be false if stakes are low."
},
{
"name": "Advancement Signals",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Real progress is when a customer takes an action that costs time, reputation, or money.",
"components": [
"Pre-ordering or paying.",
"Agreeing to pilot.",
"Letting you talk to another team member.",
"Sharing internal data.",
"Scheduling a follow-up meeting."
],
"when_it_applies": "Validating willingness to pay or seriousness.",
"limitations": "May be difficult for consumer products early on."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Running a Great Early-Stage Customer Interview",
"related_framework": "The Mom Test Rules",
"use_case": "Founder validating a problem before building.",
"steps": [
"Prepare a script of open-ended questions about the customer's life.",
"Start with concrete stories: 'Tell me about the last time you…'",
"Dig deeper into frustrations, workarounds, and costs.",
"Avoid mentioning your idea until the very end (or not at all).",
"Capture exact quotes, not interpretations.",
"Ask for commitments if the pain is strong: 'Would you prepay?', 'Can we test this with your team?'",
"Synthesize learnings across interviews and identify problem patterns."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"A B2B SaaS founder asking CFOs to walk through their exact month-end close process.",
"A B2C founder asking parents how they currently manage their child’s homework."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Pitching too early.",
"Asking hypothetical questions.",
"Taking compliments as validation.",
"Overgeneralizing from a single user story."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Number of interviews conducted.",
"Number of clear problem patterns identified.",
"Number of advancement signals (pre-orders, pilots, intros)."
]
},
{
"name": "Extracting Real Problems From Fluff",
"related_framework": "Good Questions vs Bad Questions",
"use_case": "Founder needs to differentiate opinions from facts.",
"steps": [
"When users speak in broad terms, ask for the last specific instance.",
"Probe for real consequences: time lost, money spent, stress created.",
"Ask what they tried, what failed, and why.",
"Identify triggers that cause the problem to occur.",
"Cluster responses across interviews."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"'Managing inventory is hard' → 'Tell me about the last time it caused a problem.'",
"'I would pay for this' → 'Have you paid for something similar before?'"
],
"failure_modes": [
"Accepting surface-level fluff.",
"Letting users jump into solution mode.",
"Not confirming frequency or severity."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Number of specific problem stories collected.",
"Frequency indicators per segment.",
"Severity score per problem category."
]
},
{
"name": "Testing Willingness to Pay Early",
"related_framework": "Advancement Signals",
"use_case": "Founder wants to move from problem validation to value validation.",
"steps": [
"Identify the riskiest monetization assumption.",
"Ask customers how much they currently pay to solve the problem.",
"Show them a simple concept (NOT a full product pitch).",
"Ask for a commitment: pre-order, deposit, pilot, or intro.",
"Track conversion across segments.",
"Use pricing experiments in follow-ups."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"B2B: asking for access to internal tools to test a workflow improvement.",
"B2C: collecting deposits for the first production run of a consumer gadget."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Mistaking interest for intent.",
"Underpricing due to insecurity.",
"Not testing alternative pricing models."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Commitment conversion rate.",
"Pilot acceptance rate.",
"Average willingness-to-pay across users."
]
}
]
}

{
"title": "Inspired",
"author": "Marty Cagan",
"category": "Product Leadership / Product Management",
"tags": ["product discovery", "product culture", "team structure", "modern product management", "product leadership"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "Great products are built by empowered, cross-functional product teams that deeply understand customers, validate ideas quickly, and deliver solutions that are valuable, usable, and feasible. The role of product leaders is to create the environment where these teams can thrive.",
"problem_statement": "Most companies build features instead of products, operate top-down, skip discovery, and rely on opinions instead of evidence—leading to mediocre outcomes and failed launches.",
"target_audience": "Product managers, founders, designers, engineers, and cross-functional leaders building digital products.",
"promised_transformation": "A shift from feature factories to empowered product teams that operate like the world’s best tech companies (Amazon, Netflix, Stripe, Google).",
"key_ideas": [
"Product is a team sport—PM, design, and engineering work together.",
"Empowered product teams own outcomes, not output.",
"Discovery is continuous: testing, prototyping, validating ideas before coding.",
"Risks must be addressed upfront: value, usability, feasibility, viability.",
"Product managers are not project managers—they are mini-CEOs of the product.",
"Leadership’s job is to set strategy and empower teams, not dictate features.",
"Strong product culture is the ultimate competitive advantage."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "Product Trio",
"type": "framework",
"description": "A small, cross-functional leadership group—PM, Designer, and Tech Lead—who jointly drive product discovery and solutions.",
"components": [
"Product Manager: responsible for value and viability.",
"Designer: responsible for usability.",
"Tech Lead/Engineering: responsible for feasibility.",
"Continuous collaboration during discovery."
],
"when_it_applies": "All discovery work in modern product teams.",
"limitations": "Requires high-maturity engineers and trust between roles."
},
{
"name": "Four Big Risks",
"type": "model",
"description": "Framework for de-risking ideas before development.",
"components": [
"Value Risk: Will customers buy it?",
"Usability Risk: Can customers figure it out?",
"Feasibility Risk: Can we build it?",
"Business Viability Risk: Will the solution work for stakeholders?"
],
"when_it_applies": "Before committing resources to build features.",
"limitations": "Requires discipline and willingness to discard ideas."
},
{
"name": "Continuous Discovery",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Customer learning should happen continuously—not just before development or during research cycles.",
"components": [
"Weekly customer touchpoints.",
"Rapid prototypes.",
"A/B testing, usability tests.",
"Idea backlog informed by evidence, not opinions."
],
"when_it_applies": "Every stage from PMF to scale.",
"limitations": "Requires dedicated time; many teams get stuck in delivery mode."
},
{
"name": "Empowered Product Teams",
"type": "model",
"description": "Teams with autonomy to figure out how to achieve outcomes—not implement executives’ feature lists.",
"components": [
"Outcome-based goals.",
"Clear constraints and context.",
"Autonomy over solutioning.",
"Direct access to customers and data."
],
"when_it_applies": "After basic alignment, during scaling.",
"limitations": "Fails if leadership micromanages or removes autonomy."
},
{
"name": "Opportunity-Solution Tree",
"type": "framework",
"description": "A structured way to map customer problems (opportunities) to solutions.",
"components": [
"Outcome (business or customer).",
"Opportunities (customer problems).",
"Solutions (possible approaches).",
"Experiments (tests to validate solutions)."
],
"when_it_applies": "Prioritizing discovery efforts.",
"limitations": "Teams may still jump to solutions if not disciplined."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Running Continuous Product Discovery",
"related_framework": "Continuous Discovery",
"use_case": "Teams want to shift from sporadic research to weekly discovery.",
"steps": [
"Schedule weekly customer conversations (non-negotiable).",
"Maintain a set of discovery questions tied to product goals.",
"Prototype new ideas rapidly—Figma, sketches, mock APIs.",
"Test value, usability, and feasibility early.",
"Use Opportunity Solution Tree to structure options.",
"Document learnings in a shared discovery log.",
"Integrate learnings into roadmap continuously."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"A fintech team validating onboarding flows weekly.",
"A SaaS team testing feature desirability through clickable prototypes."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Skipping user conversations due to delivery pressure.",
"Treating prototypes as mini-products.",
"Focusing on opinions instead of behavior."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Customer conversations per week.",
"Validated vs invalidated assumptions.",
"Reduction in rework or wasted sprints."
]
},
{
"name": "Transforming a Feature Factory Into an Empowered Product Team",
"related_framework": "Empowered Product Teams",
"use_case": "Leadership wants teams to own outcomes instead of executing tasks.",
"steps": [
"Shift from feature-based roadmaps to outcome-based OKRs.",
"Give teams direct access to customers and analytics.",
"Create strong product trios with PM, Designer, Tech Lead.",
"Clarify constraints: deadlines, KPIs, compliance rules.",
"Stop handing teams solutions; hand them problems.",
"Implement weekly product reviews for alignment.",
"Celebrate validated learnings—not just shipped features."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Moving from 'build X feature' to 'improve activation by 20%'.",
"Letting teams decide onboarding improvements instead of top-down planning."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Leadership still dictating solutions.",
"Teams lacking skills in discovery or strategy.",
"Confusing autonomy with lack of accountability."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Outcome achievement (activation, retention).",
"Team autonomy score.",
"Reduction in failed feature launches."
]
}
]
}

{
"title": "Crossing the Chasm",
"author": "Geoffrey Moore",
"category": "Marketing / GTM / Product Strategy",
"tags": ["technology adoption", "early adopters", "mainstream market", "positioning", "category design"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "Innovative products face a dangerous gap (the 'chasm') between early adopters who love new technology and the mainstream customers who require proof, safety, and practical value. Startups must adopt a focused, segmented strategy to cross this gap.",
"problem_statement": "Most tech startups fail because they try to scale before achieving product-market fit with a specific mainstream niche. Early adopters do not represent the mainstream.",
"target_audience": "Founders, GTM leaders, marketers, and product teams building disruptive technology.",
"promised_transformation": "A step-by-step playbook for positioning, targeting, and dominating a narrow niche before expanding into the mass market.",
"key_ideas": [
"The Technology Adoption Lifecycle contains a 'chasm' between early adopters and the early majority.",
"Early adopters love new tech; mainstream users want proven solutions.",
"You must identify a beachhead market segment and win it fully.",
"Positioning must focus on a single use case for a specific niche.",
"Whole product thinking is crucial—solve the complete customer problem, not just the core tech.",
"After dominating the beachhead, expand adjacently in a bowling pin strategy."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "Technology Adoption Lifecycle",
"type": "framework",
"description": "A model describing how different types of customers adopt new technology.",
"components": [
"Innovators (tech enthusiasts)",
"Early Adopters (visionaries)",
"Early Majority (pragmatists)",
"Late Majority",
"Laggards"
],
"when_it_applies": "GTM planning, segmentation, product launch timing.",
"limitations": "Not all markets follow the same pattern; some consumer markets behave differently."
},
{
"name": "The Chasm",
"type": "model",
"description": "A dangerous gap between early adopters and the early majority. Most startups fall into it by assuming early traction means mainstream adoption will follow naturally.",
"components": [
"Different motivations between tech enthusiasts and pragmatists.",
"Mismatch in expectations around risk, reliability, ROI.",
"Need for credibility and references to convince the majority."
],
"when_it_applies": "When moving beyond early users into broader markets.",
"limitations": "Consumer viral products may skip stages."
},
{
"name": "Beachhead Market Strategy",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Selecting a small but highly winnable market segment that can serve as a launching point for broader growth.",
"components": [
"Specific niche segment.",
"High pain problem.",
"Strong alignment with product advantages.",
"Ability to dominate quickly.",
"Clear economic buyer."
],
"when_it_applies": "Pre-scaling GTM; post initial PMF.",
"limitations": "Wrong beachhead selection can delay growth significantly."
},
{
"name": "Whole Product Concept",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Mainstream users expect a complete solution, not just the core technology.",
"components": [
"Core product.",
"Complementary features.",
"Support and onboarding.",
"Integrations.",
"Documentation.",
"Ecosystem partners."
],
"when_it_applies": "Preparing to sell to mainstream pragmatic buyers.",
"limitations": "Expensive to implement too early."
},
{
"name": "Bowling Pin Strategy",
"type": "framework",
"description": "After winning the beachhead, expand to adjacent markets in a logical sequence.",
"components": [
"Beachhead domination.",
"Adjacent segment identification.",
"Leverage references and credibility.",
"Repeatable playbook.",
"Compound expansion."
],
"when_it_applies": "Post-PMF scale-up strategy.",
"limitations": "Requires discipline to avoid premature expansion."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Selecting and Winning Your Beachhead Market",
"related_framework": "Beachhead Market Strategy",
"use_case": "Startup with early traction needs to scale but lacks mainstream adoption.",
"steps": [
"List all potential customer segments.",
"Score each segment on pain, urgency, budget, alignment with your tech.",
"Interview customers to validate segment needs.",
"Select the segment with the strongest combination of need + winnability.",
"Craft a specific positioning statement for this segment.",
"Develop whole-product solution components needed.",
"Win 5–10 lighthouse customers in the niche.",
"Use their success as proof for broader expansion."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Fintech SaaS targeting CFOs of mid-market companies, not all finance teams.",
"AI scheduling tool targeting recruiting teams before expanding to sales."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Targeting too broad an audience.",
"Confusing early adopters for mainstream users.",
"Skipping whole-product requirements."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Conversion and retention within beachhead.",
"Reference customers acquired.",
"Time to close deals in the niche."
]
},
{
"name": "Creating a Whole Product Experience",
"related_framework": "Whole Product Concept",
"use_case": "Product working for early adopters but failing with mainstream users.",
"steps": [
"Map the entire customer journey end-to-end.",
"Identify gaps between core product and full solution.",
"Add integrations, onboarding flows, documentation, support.",
"Identify ecosystem partners to fill gaps.",
"Test onboarding with pragmatic users (not early adopters).",
"Refine messaging based on reliability and ROI."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Adding training, reports, integrations for B2B buyers.",
"Offering white-glove onboarding for enterprise customers."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Assuming early adopter satisfaction predicts mainstream adoption.",
"Underinvesting in reliability and support.",
"Trying to expand before whole product is ready."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Onboarding success rate.",
"Support ticket volume.",
"Net retention in mainstream segments."
]
}
]
}

{
"title": "The Innovator’s Dilemma",
"author": "Clayton Christensen",
"category": "Innovation / Strategy / Market Disruption",
"tags": ["disruption theory", "incumbent failure", "market shifts", "innovation management", "technology cycles"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "Great companies fail not because they are poorly managed but because they follow the principles of good management—listening to customers, focusing on margins, and improving existing products—which ironically cause them to ignore emerging disruptive technologies.",
"problem_statement": "Large companies over-serve existing customers and optimize for their most profitable segments, making them unable to pursue small, low-margin innovations that later reshape markets.",
"target_audience": "Founders, executives, product leaders, strategists, and innovation teams.",
"promised_transformation": "A lens to understand how disruption works, how to identify it, and how to structure teams and strategy to survive or create disruptive innovation.",
"key_ideas": [
"Disruption starts as inferior, cheaper, simpler, or more convenient.",
"Incumbents ignore disruptive tech because their customers don't want it—yet.",
"Sustaining innovations differ from disruptive innovations.",
"Disruptors target fringe users or new markets first.",
"Incumbents cannot incubate disruptive products inside the core business.",
"The solution is autonomous teams pursuing different metrics and customers.",
"Listening blindly to customers can be fatal during disruption."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "Sustaining vs Disruptive Innovation",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Two fundamentally different innovation types that require different strategies.",
"components": [
"Sustaining Innovation: improves existing products for existing customers.",
"Disruptive Innovation: simpler, cheaper, lower-margin initially; targets fringe or new markets.",
"Trajectory Overlap: disruptors eventually move upmarket."
],
"when_it_applies": "Strategic planning, competitive analysis, evaluating new tech.",
"limitations": "Not all new technologies are disruptive; some are sustaining."
},
{
"name": "Disruption Trajectory",
"type": "model",
"description": "The path by which disruptive technologies start inferior but improve over time until they serve mainstream customers.",
"components": [
"Low-end foothold.",
"New-market foothold.",
"Upmarket movement.",
"Incumbent displacement."
],
"when_it_applies": "Market forecasting and competitive strategy.",
"limitations": "Speed varies greatly by industry."
},
{
"name": "Jobs to Be Done (JTBD) Theory",
"type": "model",
"description": "Customers 'hire' products to make progress in specific situations. Disruptors win by fulfilling overlooked or underserved jobs.",
"components": [
"Job (task or progress sought).",
"Context (situation triggering demand).",
"Constraints.",
"Current alternatives.",
"Emotional and functional drivers."
],
"when_it_applies": "Product strategy, identifying unmet needs, segmentation.",
"limitations": "Open to misinterpretation without rigorous research."
},
{
"name": "Autonomous Disruption Teams",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Incumbents should build independent teams with separate P&L and metrics to pursue disruptive innovations.",
"components": [
"Separate org structure.",
"Different KPIs (market creation, adoption, retention).",
"Freedom from core business processes.",
"Different customer targets."
],
"when_it_applies": "Exploring new markets or radical new technologies.",
"limitations": "Internal politics and resource allocation challenges."
},
{
"name": "Customer Demand vs Non-consumption",
"type": "definition",
"description": "Disruptors win by serving non-consumers—people who cannot or will not use existing solutions.",
"components": [
"Untapped demand.",
"Overpriced incumbents.",
"Accessibility barriers.",
"Convenience gaps."
],
"when_it_applies": "Market sizing and GTM for early-stage disruptors.",
"limitations": "Market must be large enough to sustain growth."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Identifying Disruptive Opportunities",
"related_framework": "Sustaining vs Disruptive Innovation",
"use_case": "Startup analyzing whether its product is truly disruptive or merely sustaining.",
"steps": [
"Identify the dominant product performance trajectory in the market.",
"Map underserved or overserved segments.",
"Evaluate if your solution is initially simpler, cheaper, or more convenient.",
"Assess whether incumbents will be motivated to ignore your market.",
"Test early adoption with fringe users or non-consumers.",
"Track improvement trajectory to determine when mainstream viability emerges."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Lower-cost SaaS replacing expensive enterprise tools.",
"Mobile-based products replacing desktop-heavy workflows."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Mistaking sustaining improvements for disruption.",
"Targeting mainstream customers too early.",
"Underestimating incumbent response speed."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Adoption among fringe segments.",
"Improvement rate in product performance.",
"Expansion into higher-value segments."
]
},
{
"name": "Building an Autonomous Disruption Team",
"related_framework": "Autonomous Disruption Teams",
"use_case": "Company exploring new disruptive tech that would cannibalize current revenue.",
"steps": [
"Define disruptive opportunity that conflicts with core business.",
"Create separate team with independent decision rights.",
"Set different KPIs based on learning and early adoption.",
"Ensure team is insulated from core processes and incentives.",
"Give direct access to leadership for sponsorship.",
"Review progress quarterly but avoid micromanagement."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Enterprise software company incubating a self-serve SMB product.",
"Hardware manufacturer testing lightweight consumer IoT devices."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Core business strangling the new initiative.",
"Applying enterprise KPIs to early-stage disruptions.",
"Cannibalization fear stopping experimentation."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Early adoption within target fringe market.",
"Learning velocity.",
"Independence and autonomy health score."
]
}
]
}

{
"title": "The Innovator’s Solution",
"author": "Clayton Christensen & Michael Raynor",
"category": "Innovation / Strategy",
"tags": ["disruption", "JTBD", "market creation", "business model innovation", "growth strategy"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "Companies can respond to—and even create—disruptive innovation by systematically identifying underserved or non-consuming markets, designing business models aligned to disruptive potential, and building autonomous teams to pursue them.",
"problem_statement": "Successful companies often fail to grow because they rely on sustaining innovation for existing customers, missing opportunities to create new growth engines through disruptive markets.",
"target_audience": "Founders, executives, investors, and product leaders working on market-creating innovations.",
"promised_transformation": "A systematic methodology for recognizing disruptive opportunities, designing the right business model, and launching products that can become new growth engines.",
"key_ideas": [
"Disruption is predictable when you understand non-consumption.",
"New growth comes from new markets, not better versions of old products.",
"Jobs to Be Done is the lens to uncover true customer demand.",
"Business models—not technology—enable disruption.",
"Resource allocation must match the innovation type.",
"Autonomous teams are essential for disruptive projects.",
"Growth stalls when companies ignore low-end or new-market footholds."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "Jobs To Be Done (JTBD)",
"type": "model",
"description": "Customers 'hire' products to get specific jobs done in their lives. Innovation succeeds when it fulfills these jobs better than current alternatives.",
"components": [
"Functional Job.",
"Emotional Job.",
"Social Job.",
"Context and constraints.",
"Compensating behaviors and workarounds."
],
"when_it_applies": "Identifying market needs, product differentiation, innovation direction.",
"limitations": "Requires deep qualitative research; easily misapplied."
},
{
"name": "New-Market Disruption",
"type": "framework",
"description": "A disruptive innovation that creates an entirely new class of customers who previously could not access a solution.",
"components": [
"Non-consumers.",
"Lower performance threshold.",
"Simplicity or affordability.",
"New business model alignment."
],
"when_it_applies": "When exploring products for people currently not served by incumbents.",
"limitations": "Early revenue is small; may be ignored internally."
},
{
"name": "Low-End Disruption",
"type": "framework",
"description": "A product enters at the bottom of an existing market, serving over-served customers with a simpler, cheaper alternative.",
"components": [
"Over-served customers.",
"Good-enough performance.",
"Lower cost structure.",
"Upward movement over time."
],
"when_it_applies": "When incumbents overshoot customer needs.",
"limitations": "Must be paired with a lower-cost business model to work."
},
{
"name": "Disruptive Growth Engine",
"type": "model",
"description": "A repeatable system for identifying, testing, and scaling disruptive opportunities.",
"components": [
"Opportunity identification.",
"Separate business model.",
"Autonomous team.",
"Appropriate metrics (adoption, usage).",
"Leadership sponsorship."
],
"when_it_applies": "Launching new product lines or new markets.",
"limitations": "Requires long-term patience."
},
{
"name": "Using the Right Business Model",
"type": "principle",
"description": "The business model must match the innovation type; sustaining innovations and disruptive innovations cannot share the same model.",
"components": [
"Profit formula.",
"Processes and norms.",
"Resources.",
"Customer segments."
],
"when_it_applies": "Designing or evaluating new growth initiatives.",
"limitations": "Difficult politically; cannibalization fears."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Discovering Jobs to Be Done",
"related_framework": "Jobs To Be Done (JTBD)",
"use_case": "A team wants to uncover real customer jobs to guide product strategy.",
"steps": [
"Interview customers around recent purchases or use cases.",
"Probe for moments of struggle and dissatisfaction.",
"Map functional, emotional, and social jobs.",
"Identify compensating behaviors and hacks.",
"Group jobs into high-pain, frequent categories.",
"Convert top jobs into testable product hypotheses."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"A payment startup discovering that SMBs hire tools to reduce reconciliation anxiety, not just process payments.",
"A workflow tool realizing users want to 'feel organized' emotionally, not just manage tasks functionally."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Collecting wishlists instead of jobs.",
"Focusing on solutions instead of motivations.",
"Ignoring emotional context."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Frequency of job occurrence.",
"Severity ratings.",
"Adoption of prototypes aligned to JTBD."
]
},
{
"name": "Launching a Disruptive Innovation Unit",
"related_framework": "Disruptive Growth Engine",
"use_case": "A company wants to explore low-margin or new-market opportunities.",
"steps": [
"Define the disruptive opportunity clearly.",
"Build a small autonomous team with separate KPIs.",
"Design a business model optimized for low-end or non-consumption markets.",
"Run fast experiments with fringe customers.",
"Track adoption, not profitability early on.",
"Gradually move upmarket as product improves.",
"Maintain separation from core business until maturity."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Enterprise SaaS launching a self-serve SMB product.",
"Premium hardware company launching a simpler consumer line."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Using core business metrics too early.",
"Allowing core team to influence product decisions.",
"Premature integration with main product line."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Adoption among non-consumers.",
"Unit economics improvements over time.",
"Movement upmarket (ARPU trends)."
]
}
]
}

{
"title": "Blitzscaling",
"author": "Reid Hoffman & Chris Yeh",
"category": "Scaling / Growth Strategy",
"tags": ["hypergrowth", "organizational scaling", "startup phases", "management debt", "responsible hypergrowth"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "Blitzscaling is the strategy of prioritizing speed over efficiency in the face of massive opportunity. It involves embracing uncertainty, rapidly evolving org structures, and sacrificing optimization to achieve market dominance.",
"problem_statement": "Most companies optimize too early, missing the brief window where winner-take-most markets can be captured through hypergrowth.",
"target_audience": "Founders, growth leaders, and executives in winner-take-all markets.",
"promised_transformation": "A framework for when and how to blitzscale responsibly, and how to navigate the chaos of rapid headcount, product, and market expansion.",
"key_ideas": [
"Speed > efficiency when market dynamics reward dominance.",
"Blitzscaling is appropriate only in massive, winner-take-most markets.",
"Each stage of growth requires different leadership and processes.",
"Management debt builds quickly during rapid scaling.",
"Chaos is inevitable; the goal is to survive it without imploding.",
"Transitions between stages are the biggest risks.",
"Blitzscaling ends when efficiency begins."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "Blitzscaling Stages",
"type": "framework",
"description": "The phases a company moves through as it scales at extreme speed.",
"components": [
"Family (1–9 people).",
"Tribe (10–49).",
"Village (50–149).",
"City (150–499).",
"Nation (500+)."
],
"when_it_applies": "Planning org changes during rapid scale.",
"limitations": "Stage boundaries vary widely by company."
},
{
"name": "The Five Growth Factors",
"type": "model",
"description": "Conditions required for blitzscaling to make sense.",
"components": [
"Market Size.",
"Distribution Advantage.",
"High Gross Margins.",
"Network Effects.",
"First-Scaler Advantage."
],
"when_it_applies": "Determining if blitzscaling is justified.",
"limitations": "If these factors are weak, blitzscaling destroys capital."
},
{
"name": "The Five Growth Limiters",
"type": "model",
"description": "Constraints that slow scaling.",
"components": [
"Product/Market Fit.",
"Operational Scalability.",
"Financial Scalability.",
"Human Scalability.",
"Management Scalability."
],
"when_it_applies": "Diagnosing bottlenecks during hypergrowth.",
"limitations": "Removing one limiter often reveals another."
},
{
"name": "Responsible Blitzscaling",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Balancing growth with risk mitigation to avoid collapse.",
"components": [
"Monitor unit economics.",
"Invest in infrastructure just-in-time.",
"Prioritize culture intentionally.",
"Address management debt early."
],
"when_it_applies": "Applying blitzscaling in high-risk environments.",
"limitations": "Some chaos cannot be prevented—only managed."
},
{
"name": "Management Debt",
"type": "definition",
"description": "Shortcuts in people and processes taken for speed that create long-term problems.",
"components": [
"Underdeveloped processes.",
"Poor hiring decisions.",
"Lack of documentation.",
"Misaligned incentives."
],
"when_it_applies": "Rapid scaling phases.",
"limitations": "If unmanaged, can cripple scaling."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Deciding Whether to Blitzscale",
"related_framework": "The Five Growth Factors",
"use_case": "Founder needs to determine if hypergrowth is rational.",
"steps": [
"Evaluate market size (TAM).",
"Assess presence of network effects.",
"Analyze distribution advantages (viral loops, partnerships).",
"Check gross margin potential.",
"Identify if winner-take-most dynamics exist.",
"Model scenarios with and without blitzscaling.",
"Decide whether speed > efficiency."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Marketplace with clear network effects.",
"SaaS tool becoming a system-of-record category."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Blitzscaling into a small or stable market.",
"Ignoring early unit economics.",
"Underestimating organizational chaos."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Growth rate relative to competitors.",
"Spend-to-growth ratio.",
"Network effect strength (K-factor)."
]
},
{
"name": "Managing Hypergrowth Chaos",
"related_framework": "Management Debt",
"use_case": "Startup experiencing uncontrolled scaling issues.",
"steps": [
"Identify management debt hotspots (people, process).",
"Create temporary scalable processes (SOPs, wikis).",
"Hire key executives or managers.",
"Introduce lightweight performance management.",
"Add internal communication rhythms.",
"Implement infrastructure upgrades (tech, data, tools)."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Implementing weekly all-hands during 3× headcount growth.",
"Hiring a Head of People after 40 employees."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Trying to add full bureaucratic processes too early.",
"Ignoring culture during hypergrowth.",
"Hiring too fast without calibration."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Onboarding success rate.",
"Employee turnover.",
"Reliability of operational systems."
]
}
]
}

{
"title": "Who",
"author": "Geoff Smart & Randy Street",
"category": "Hiring / Talent / Leadership",
"tags": ["recruiting", "A-players", "talent system", "interviewing", "hiring process"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "The biggest problem in business is failed hiring. A-players can be consistently selected through a disciplined recruiting method called the A Method.",
"problem_statement": "Most hiring is based on gut feel, resumes, or unstructured interviews—leading to mis-hires, culture problems, and massive cost.",
"target_audience": "Founders, hiring managers, HR teams, executives.",
"promised_transformation": "A repeatable system to define roles clearly, attract the right talent, interview rigorously, and close top performers.",
"key_ideas": [
"Define success through a Scorecard, not job descriptions.",
"Use a structured sourcing strategy to fill the funnel.",
"Conduct structured interviews (Screen, Who, Focus).",
"Evaluate candidates based on evidence, not enthusiasm.",
"Reference checks are non-negotiable.",
"Great hiring prevents culture debt and future org failures."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "The A Method",
"type": "framework",
"description": "A structured hiring system with four components: Scorecard, Source, Select, Sell.",
"components": [
"Scorecard: define outcomes and competencies.",
"Source: proactive sourcing methods.",
"Select: structured interviews.",
"Sell: closing A-players effectively."
],
"when_it_applies": "All hiring from junior roles to executives.",
"limitations": "Time-consuming to implement fully."
},
{
"name": "Scorecard",
"type": "model",
"description": "A document defining success expectations and required competencies for the role.",
"components": [
"Mission (role purpose).",
"Outcomes (measurable results).",
"Competencies (skills/behaviors)."
],
"when_it_applies": "Before interviewing any candidate.",
"limitations": "Must be specific and measurable; generic scorecards are useless."
},
{
"name": "Structured Interviews (Screen, Who, Focus)",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Three interview formats that gather true evidence on capabilities and fit.",
"components": [
"Screen Interview: quick fit assessment.",
"Who Interview: chronological career walkthrough.",
"Focus Interview: deep dive into outcomes and competencies."
],
"when_it_applies": "Interview stages for all serious candidates.",
"limitations": "Candidates may 'game' chronological walkthroughs if not probed deeply."
},
{
"name": "Topgrading Principles",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Hire only A-players—those who consistently deliver superior results for the role level.",
"components": [
"Evidence over intuition.",
"Consistent structured evaluation.",
"Pattern recognition across roles."
],
"when_it_applies": "Leadership hiring or roles with high responsibility.",
"limitations": "Not every role requires an A-player; cost vs need must be balanced."
},
{
"name": "Reference Checking (TORC Method)",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Threat of reference check (TORC) encourages honest answers and validation.",
"components": [
"Candidate generates reference list.",
"You contact former managers directly.",
"Ask evidence-based performance questions."
],
"when_it_applies": "Final hiring stage.",
"limitations": "Some companies restrict reference conversations."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Creating a High-Quality Scorecard",
"related_framework": "Scorecard",
"use_case": "Founder wants clarity on what success looks like for a role.",
"steps": [
"Define the mission of the role in one sentence.",
"List 3–8 key measurable outcomes.",
"Define required competencies based on past success patterns.",
"Validate scorecard with leadership team.",
"Use scorecard to filter and evaluate candidates."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"A B2B SaaS scorecard with metrics: pipeline growth, win rate, ramp time.",
"A PM scorecard focusing on activation, retention, roadmap delivery."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Writing vague outcomes.",
"Focusing on personality instead of capabilities.",
"Not aligning success metrics to company goals."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Scorecard consistency across roles.",
"Percentage of hires meeting outcomes.",
"Ramp-up speed of new hires."
]
},
{
"name": "Running a Great Who Interview",
"related_framework": "Structured Interviews (Screen, Who, Focus)",
"use_case": "Hiring manager evaluating a candidate's historical performance.",
"steps": [
"Walk through each job chronologically.",
"Ask: What were you hired to do?",
"Ask: What did you accomplish?",
"Ask: What were your biggest mistakes?",
"Ask: What changes would you make?",
"Ask: Why did you leave?",
"Probe for evidence, not stories."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Uncovering red flags such as inconsistent results.",
"Identifying patterns of growth and performance."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Letting candidate dominate with vague narratives.",
"Not pushing for specifics.",
"Ignoring repeated weaknesses."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Signal strength from interviews.",
"Hiring success rate.",
"Performance of new hires after 6 months."
]
}
]
}

{
"title": "Measure What Matters",
"author": "John Doerr",
"category": "Goal-Setting / Leadership / Execution",
"tags": ["OKRs", "goal setting", "alignment", "execution", "strategy"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "Objectives and Key Results (OKRs) provide a simple but powerful goal-setting system that increases focus, alignment, accountability, and execution across teams.",
"problem_statement": "Most organizations lack clarity and alignment—teams work hard but pull in different directions, causing inefficiency and missed goals.",
"target_audience": "Founders, executives, managers, and product leaders.",
"promised_transformation": "A system for defining ambitious goals (Objectives) and measurable outcomes (Key Results) that drive clarity and accountability.",
"key_ideas": [
"OKRs create focus on what matters most.",
"Objectives must be inspiring and qualitative.",
"Key Results must be measurable and outcome-focused.",
"Transparency and alignment across teams is essential.",
"OKRs work best with CFRs (Conversations, Feedback, Recognition).",
"Stretch goals create innovation and push boundaries.",
"Regular reviews ensure course-correction."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "OKR Framework",
"type": "framework",
"description": "A goal-setting system with qualitative Objectives and measurable Key Results.",
"components": [
"Objective: What we want to achieve.",
"Key Results: How we measure success.",
"Owner: Who is responsible.",
"Cadence: Quarterly or annual."
],
"when_it_applies": "Strategic planning, execution, alignment.",
"limitations": "Poorly written OKRs lead to confusion."
},
{
"name": "CFR (Conversations, Feedback, Recognition)",
"type": "principle",
"description": "A management system that complements OKRs with continuous communication.",
"components": [
"Conversations.",
"Feedback loops.",
"Recognition for progress."
],
"when_it_applies": "Performance management.",
"limitations": "Often ignored, weakening OKR effectiveness."
},
{
"name": "Types of OKRs (Committed vs Aspirational)",
"type": "model",
"description": "Two categories of OKRs with differing difficulty.",
"components": [
"Committed: Must be achieved.",
"Aspirational: Stretch goals."
],
"when_it_applies": "Strategic goal-setting.",
"limitations": "Mixing types creates misalignment."
},
{
"name": "Alignment and Transparency",
"type": "principle",
"description": "OKRs should be visible company-wide to align teams.",
"components": [
"Shared dashboards.",
"Inter-team dependency mapping.",
"CEO and leadership OKRs first."
],
"when_it_applies": "Cross-functional collaboration.",
"limitations": "Overexposure may create pressure without support."
},
{
"name": "Quarterly OKR Cycles",
"type": "framework",
"description": "The cadence for writing, tracking, and reviewing OKRs.",
"components": [
"Planning.",
"Mid-cycle check.",
"Final scoring.",
"Retrospective."
],
"when_it_applies": "Execution cycles.",
"limitations": "Too frequent cycles can overwhelm teams."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Writing Effective OKRs",
"related_framework": "OKR Framework",
"use_case": "Teams need clarity and focus.",
"steps": [
"Define 1–3 Objectives that are inspiring and clear.",
"Write 3–5 measurable Key Results per Objective.",
"Ensure Key Results measure outcomes, not tasks.",
"Assign ownership.",
"Align cross-functionally.",
"Publish and share with the organization."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Objective: Improve retention. KR: Increase 90-day retention from 25% to 40%.",
"Objective: Grow revenue. KR: Generate ₹50 Lakhs in quarterly recurring revenue."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Too many OKRs.",
"Key Results written as tasks.",
"No owner or accountability."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Objective completion rate.",
"KR scoring accuracy.",
"Alignment across departments."
]
},
{
"name": "Running Quarterly OKR Reviews",
"related_framework": "Quarterly OKR Cycles",
"use_case": "Leadership wants structured planning.",
"steps": [
"Conduct mid-quarter check-in.",
"Review KR progress and blockers.",
"Identify cross-team dependencies.",
"Adjust priorities if needed.",
"End-of-quarter scoring.",
"Retrospective on what worked and failed."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Leadership OKR review meetings.",
"Slack/Notion dashboards tracking OKR progress."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Ignoring KRs until quarter-end.",
"No retrospectives.",
"Blaming individuals instead of improving process."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Cycle consistency.",
"KR scoring accuracy.",
"Execution velocity."
]
}
]
}

{
"title": "Play Bigger",

"category": "Category Design / Strategy",
"tags": ["category creation", "positioning", "strategy", "market design", "lightning strikes"],
