]
}
]
}

{
"title": "Contagious",
"author": "Jonah Berger",
"category": "Marketing / Virality / Word-of-Mouth",
"tags": ["virality", "word of mouth", "behavioral marketing", "growth", "GTM", "STEPPS"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "Ideas, products, and messages spread not by luck but by science. Virality is driven by six psychological principles (STEPPS): Social Currency, Triggers, Emotion, Public, Practical Value, and Stories.",
"problem_statement": "Most founders attempt virality through randomness — gimmicks, giveaways, stunts. But sustainable virality requires designing products and messages that people *want* to share because it makes them look good, feel something, or helps others.",
"target_audience": "Founders, marketers, storytellers, growth teams, content creators, brand strategists.",
"promised_transformation": "A playbook for making your product, brand, or content inherently shareable by leveraging human psychology and designing word-of-mouth into the experience.",
"key_ideas": [
"Word-of-mouth is more powerful and more trusted than advertising.",
"Virality is engineered using STEPPS — not random luck.",
"People share things that make them look good (Social Currency).",
"Triggers ensure your idea stays top of mind and is recalled frequently.",
"High-arousal emotions (awe, anger, humor) drive sharing.",
"Public visibility makes private behaviors contagious.",
"Practical Value makes people feel helpful when they share.",
"Stories are vessels that carry your brand message naturally."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "STEPPS Framework",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Six psychological drivers that cause ideas, products, and content to spread organically.",
"components": [
"Social Currency",
"Triggers",
"Emotion",
"Public",
"Practical Value",
"Stories"
],
"when_it_applies": "Marketing, content creation, product design, viral loops.",
"limitations": "Not every product needs all 6; overusing them can feel contrived."
},
{
"name": "Social Currency",
"type": "principle",
"description": "People share things that make them look good or feel special.",
"components": [
"Insider knowledge",
"Status and identity signaling",
"Remarkability",
"Game mechanics and achievements"
],
"when_it_applies": "Branding, product features, referral loops, exclusive communities.",
"limitations": "If the reward feels artificial, people disengage."
},
{
"name": "Triggers",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Environmental cues that keep ideas top of mind and prompt sharing.",
"components": [
"Contextual reminders",
"Daily/weekly habits",
"Cultural associations",
"Seasonality"
],
"when_it_applies": "Content strategy, naming, messaging, product stickiness.",
"limitations": "Triggers without value fail to convert to meaningful engagement."
},
{
"name": "Emotion",
"type": "principle",
"description": "High-arousal emotions (awe, excitement, anger, humor) drive sharing more than low-arousal emotions (sadness, contentment).",
"components": [
"Awe",
"Anger",
"Amusement",
"Anxiety",
"Joy"
],
"when_it_applies": "Content creation, ads, storytelling.",
"limitations": "Emotional manipulation can backfire."
},
{
"name": "Public",
"type": "principle",
"description": "People imitate what they can observe. Making behavior visible increases adoption.",
"components": [
"Built-in visibility",
"Badges and public proof",
"Physical and digital signals",
"‘Monkey see, monkey do’ influence"
],
"when_it_applies": "Referral programs, product UX, community design.",
"limitations": "Visible behavior must lead to positive association."
},
{
"name": "Practical Value",
"type": "principle",
"description": "People share useful things because it makes them feel helpful.",
"components": [
"Tips, hacks, shortcuts",
"How-tos",
"Tools and calculators",
"Checklists and frameworks"
],
"when_it_applies": "Lead magnets, content, onboarding.",
"limitations": "Low-value tips get ignored; must be truly helpful."
},
{
"name": "Stories",
"type": "framework",
"description": "People remember stories, not stats. Embedding your product inside a story makes it spread naturally.",
"components": [
"Trojan horse stories",
"Narratives with a lesson",
"Characters and tension",
"Brand embedded as the ‘reason why’"
],
"when_it_applies": "Brand building, ads, pitches, viral videos.",
"limitations": "Story must naturally tie to product; forced stories don’t spread."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Applying STEPPS to Product Marketing",
"related_framework": "STEPPS",
"use_case": "Startup wants organic virality without relying on paid ads.",
"steps": [
"Identify which STEPPS elements best match your product.",
"Add Social Currency by giving users insider access or achievements.",
"Design Trigger moments tied to daily habits (morning routines, calendar events, product usage).",
"Embed high-arousal emotional hooks into onboarding or content.",
"Make user success visible (public dashboards, badges, branding).",
"Create practical-value content that solves major pain points.",
"Wrap the value in stories where your product is central."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Duolingo’s gamification + triggers + public streaks.",
"Notion templates spreading through Practical Value + Stories.",
"Calendly’s link-sharing as a built-in Public mechanism."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Using all STEPPS instead of picking 1–3 that fit.",
"Virality that attracts wrong users.",
"Artificial triggers that don’t align with product."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Referral and invite rate.",
"Organic traffic growth.",
"Virality coefficient (K-factor).",
"Retention of users acquired through WOM."
]
},
{
"name": "Designing Shareable Lead Magnets & Content",
"related_framework": "Practical Value + Emotion",
"use_case": "Founder wants lead magnets that spread organically.",
"steps": [
"Pick a narrow, high-intensity problem.",
"Create a tool/template/checklist that gives immediate value.",
"Add an emotional hook (awe, surprise, humor).",
"Format in visually shareable form (carousel, PDF, thread).",
"Use a title that signals Social Currency (‘insider secrets’).",
"Add a Trigger (e.g., weekly routine or industry event).",
"Encourage sharing through subtle CTAs (‘pass this to someone who needs it’)."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Founder’s ‘7 scripts that got me 112 meetings’—high practical value + social currency.",
"A market sizing calculator shared widely in startup circles.",
"AI prompts list that spreads through communities."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Too generic (low-value).",
"No emotional hook.",
"No connection to core product."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Shares per view.",
"Lead magnet virality.",
"Email capture rate.",
"Lead → customer conversion from viral sources."
]
},
{
"name": "Building Virality Into the Product Itself",
"related_framework": "Public + Social Currency",
"use_case": "SaaS startup wants product-led growth through embedded virality.",
"steps": [
"Identify actions users naturally share (output, achievements, reports).",
"Build ‘public visibility’ into these actions (share buttons, public URLs).",
"Add subtle Social Currency (streaks, badges, early adopter tag).",
"Turn core features into shareable artifacts (templates, portfolios, results).",
"Ensure shared artifacts lead new users directly to your onboarding.",
"Automate follow-up sequences for new referred users.",
"Track viral loops and optimize weakest steps."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Figma’s shareable design files.",
"Loom’s shareable video links.",
"Notion template galleries."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Over-gamification.",
"Sharing features that add no value.",
"Artifacts that do not link back to activation."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Viral coefficient (K).",
"Invite → signup conversion.",
"Shared artifacts produced per user.",
"Referral retention."
]
}
]
}

{
"title": "Made to Stick",
"author": "Chip Heath & Dan Heath",
"category": "Messaging / Storytelling / Communication",
"tags": ["storytelling", "communication", "content creation", "marketing", "behavioral psychology", "idea design"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "Ideas that ‘stick’—that people remember, share, and act upon—follow a predictable formula summarized by the SUCCESs framework: Simple, Unexpected, Concrete, Credible, Emotional, Stories.",
"problem_statement": "Most startup narratives, pitches, and content fail because they are too abstract, too complex, and too rational. Sticky ideas are simple, surprising, concrete, emotional, and wrapped in story.",
"target_audience": "Founders, storytellers, marketers, educators, sales leaders, content creators, product and brand teams.",
"promised_transformation": "A repeatable method to craft messages, pitches, and stories that are memorable, impactful, and widely shareable.",
"key_ideas": [
"Sticky ideas follow the SUCCESs framework: Simple, Unexpected, Concrete, Credible, Emotional, Stories.",
"The ‘Curse of Knowledge’ makes experts communicate poorly because they forget what it’s like not to know.",
"Simplicity = finding the core of the idea, not dumbing it down.",
"Surprise grabs attention; insight keeps attention.",
"Concrete ideas are easier to remember and act on.",
"Credibility comes from vivid details, statistics, or trusted sources.",
"Emotion drives action — people act when they care.",
"Stories encode complex ideas into repeatable, memorable packages."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "SUCCESs Framework",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Six principles that make ideas memorable and spreadable.",
"components": [
"Simple",
"Unexpected",
"Concrete",
"Credible",
"Emotional",
"Stories"
],
"when_it_applies": "Pitching, ads, content, product messaging, onboarding, virality.",
"limitations": "Requires effort to reduce complex ideas to their essence without oversimplifying."
},
{
"name": "The Curse of Knowledge",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Experts struggle to empathize with beginners, making communication unclear or overwhelming.",
"components": [
"Overuse of jargon",
"Assuming shared context",
"Too much detail",
"Abstract explanations"
],
"when_it_applies": "All communication involving experts → novices.",
"limitations": "Difficult for domain experts to self-correct."
},
{
"name": "Commander's Intent",
"type": "principle",
"description": "A military-inspired method for creating simplicity — define the single most important goal.",
"components": [
"Define core message or outcome.",
"Strip away everything else.",
"Communicate only the essential."
],
"when_it_applies": "Startups overwhelmed by complexity, pitch decks, company vision.",
"limitations": "Too much simplification risks misunderstanding the nuance."
},
{
"name": "Concrete Messaging",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Concrete ideas use sensory details that the human mind can visualize effortlessly.",
"components": [
"Specific examples",
"Analogies",
"Sensory language",
"Demonstrations",
"Real-world details"
],
"when_it_applies": "Demos, onboarding, landing pages, instructions.",
"limitations": "Concrete examples must still tie back to strategy."
},
{
"name": "Three Types of Stories",
"type": "framework",
"description": "All sticky stories fall into three archetypes.",
"components": [
"Challenge Stories (overcoming obstacles).",
"Connection Stories (relationships that inspire action).",
"Creative Stories (innovation and problem-solving)."
],
"when_it_applies": "Brand storytelling, founder stories, viral content.",
"limitations": "Stories must embed the core message — entertaining alone is insufficient."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Crafting a SUCCESs-Based Pitch",
"related_framework": "SUCCESs Framework",
"use_case": "A startup wants a memorable, effective pitch or landing page narrative.",
"steps": [
"Identify the core idea (Commander’s Intent).",
"Simplify the message to 1–2 sentences.",
"Add an unexpected hook (counterintuitive insight or surprising fact).",
"Make the idea concrete using real-world examples or demos.",
"Add credibility (stats, proof points, case studies).",
"Activate emotion by linking to customer aspirations or pain.",
"Wrap the message in a simple, human story.",
"Test recall: see what people remember 24 hours later."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Airbnb early pitch: ‘Book rooms with locals instead of hotels’ (simple, concrete, emotional).",
"Dropbox demo video: concrete, unexpected (a founder’s screen recording), built-in story."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Overloading with too much detail.",
"No emotional hook.",
"Too abstract (‘An AI-driven productivity solution’).",
"No anchor in concrete examples."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Message recall rate.",
"Pitch conversion rate.",
"Landing page clarity score.",
"Time-on-page for narrative sections."
]
},
{
"name": "Turning Product Features Into Concrete Benefits",
"related_framework": "Concrete Messaging",
"use_case": "Startup wants to make product value instantly understandable.",
"steps": [
"List core features.",
"Translate each into a concrete benefit using ‘so that…’ statements.",
"Replace abstract language with specific sensory or practical examples.",
"Create analogies that map unfamiliar concepts to familiar ones.",
"Use before/after stories to make benefits memorable.",
"Test with users: keep only benefits that produce clear mental pictures."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"'Automated reporting' → 'You get a board-ready report in 60 seconds.’",
"'AI-powered insights' → 'It tells you exactly which customers are about to churn — before they do.’"
],
"failure_modes": [
"Relying on technical jargon (‘intelligent dashboards’).",
"Benefits that can't be visualized.",
"Overusing metaphors that confuse meaning."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"User comprehension score.",
"Demo → trial conversion.",
"Engagement with feature explanations."
]
},
{
"name": "Designing Viral Content Using SUCCESs",
"related_framework": "SUCCESs Framework",
"use_case": "Founder wants content that gets shared consistently.",
"steps": [
"Start with a counterintuitive insight (Unexpected).",
"Present it through a relatable story.",
"Add concrete examples and visuals.",
"Use emotional triggers (awe, outrage, inspiration).",
"Inject a credibility hook (data, personal experience, expert quote).",
"Add a simple, actionable takeaway.",
"End with a natural sharing cue (‘send this to someone who needs this’)."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Carousel: ‘The 7 lies founders believe about PMF’ (unexpected + emotional).",
"Video story: ‘How we almost died before our first pivot’ (story + emotion + credibility)."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Too educational without story.",
"Too much story without a core lesson.",
"Highly emotional but not actionable.",
"Generic insights that aren’t surprising."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Share rate per impression.",
"Completion rate on video content.",
"Save rate for carousels.",
"Follower growth from content spikes."
]
}
]
}

{
"title": "The 22 Immutable Laws of Marketing",
"author": "Al Ries & Jack Trout",
"category": "Marketing / Strategy / Positioning",
"tags": ["marketing laws", "positioning", "strategy", "brand building", "competitive advantage"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "Marketing success is governed by fundamental psychological and strategic laws. When brands violate these laws, they suffer — when they align with them, they dominate. The laws revolve around perception, category creation, leadership, focus, and differentiation.",
"problem_statement": "Founders and marketers often rely on tactics, creativity, or budget instead of understanding the strategic laws of markets and human perception — leading to wasted spend, unclear positioning, and poor differentiation.",
"target_audience": "Founders, marketers, brand strategists, GTM leaders, product leaders, growth teams.",
"promised_transformation": "A timeless, strategic mindset that helps you avoid common marketing mistakes, carve strong positions, and build brands that dominate categories.",
"key_ideas": [
"Law of Leadership: It’s better to be first than better.",
"Law of Category: If you can’t be first in a category, create a new one.",
"Law of the Mind: Being first in the mind is more important than being first in the market.",
"Law of Perception: Marketing is a battle of perceptions, not products.",
"Law of Focus: Own one word in the customer's mind.",
"Law of Exclusivity: Two brands cannot own the same word.",
"Law of Sacrifice: To win, you must give up something.",
"Law of Line Extension: Stretching your brand weakens it.",
"Law of Opposites: If you are not the leader, leverage contrast.",
"Law of Attributes: For every attribute, pick the opposite strong one.",
"Law of Candor: Admit a negative to gain trust.",
"Law of Unpredictability: You can’t predict the future; build adaptability.",
"Law of Hype: True success is not preceded by hype.",
"Law of Acceleration: Trends build brands, not fads.",
"Law of Resources: Ideas need sufficient resources to survive."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "The 22 Laws Summary Framework",
"type": "framework",
"description": "A structured look at the 22 laws that govern marketing success.",
"components": [
"Leadership",
"Category",
"Mind",
"Perception",
"Focus",
"Exclusivity",
"Ladder",
"Duality",
"Opposites",
"Division",
"Perspective",
"Line Extension",
"Sacrifice",
"Attributes",
"Candor",
"Singularity",
"Unpredictability",
"Success",
"Failure",
"Hype",
"Acceleration",
"Resources"
],
"when_it_applies": "Strategic planning, new product launches, category creation, positioning, branding.",
"limitations": "Some laws can conflict; requires judgment to apply contextually."
},
{
"name": "Law of Leadership",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Being first in the mind is better than being better. Category leaders dominate share and perception.",
"components": [
"First mover = mental authority.",
"Followers must reposition, not outspend.",
"Perceived pioneers win long-term."
],
"when_it_applies": "Launches, category creation, new GTM motion.",
"limitations": "Being first in market ≠ being first in mind; timing and messaging matter."
},
{
"name": "Law of Category",
"type": "principle",
"description": "If you can’t be first in a category, create a new subcategory you can dominate.",
"components": [
"Niche creation.",
"Subcategory naming.",
"Position as the clear leader of that subcategory."
],
"when_it_applies": "Crowded markets, late entrants, differentiation.",
"limitations": "New categories require education and time."
},
{
"name": "Law of Focus",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Strong brands focus on one word, one attribute, one idea.",
"components": [
"Volvo = Safety",
"FedEx = Overnight",
"Google = Search"
],
"when_it_applies": "Brand messaging, identity, GTM positioning.",
"limitations": "Hard for founders who fear missing out."
},
{
"name": "Law of Exclusivity",
"type": "principle",
"description": "No two brands can own the same word in the customer’s mind.",
"components": [
"Leader claims the primary word.",
"Challenger must choose a different attribute."
],
"when_it_applies": "Competitive positioning, naming, branding.",
"limitations": "Brands often mistakenly copy their rivals’ claims."
},
{
"name": "Law of Sacrifice",
"type": "principle",
"description": "To succeed, a brand must sacrifice: target market, product line, or constant change.",
"components": [
"Narrow target audience.",
"Specialize product line.",
"Avoid frequent strategy changes."
],
"when_it_applies": "Brand expansion, product roadmaps.",
"limitations": "Sacrifice feels risky; founders often resist focus."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Finding Your One Word (Law of Focus)",
"related_framework": "Law of Focus",
"use_case": "Startup wants a sharp, memorable position in the customer’s mind.",
"steps": [
"List the top 3 attributes customers care about in your category.",
"Identify which attribute the leader currently owns.",
"Choose one meaningful attribute no competitor dominates.",
"Rewrite your entire messaging around that attribute.",
"Test whether customers recall this attribute after reading your homepage.",
"Remove anything that contradicts the one-word positioning."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"A new CRM focusing on ‘speed’ instead of ‘all-in-one’.",
"A hiring tool owning the word ‘precision’ versus generic ‘AI hiring’.",
"A meditation app owning the word ‘science-backed’ instead of just ‘calm’."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Choosing abstract words (‘innovation’, ‘smart’).",
"Owning multiple words.",
"Using a word already owned by a leader."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Message recall tests.",
"Homepage conversion rate.",
"Brand association score."
]
},
{
"name": "Creating a New Subcategory (Law of Category)",
"related_framework": "Law of Category",
"use_case": "Startup is entering a saturated market with strong leaders.",
"steps": [
"Identify dominant players and their positioning.",
"Find underserved segments or new use cases.",
"Name your subcategory (e.g., ‘AI-first accounting’, ‘Founder-centric CRM’).",
"Create proof that your subcategory solves a different problem.",
"Communicate why the old category is insufficient.",
"Repeat category framing everywhere (website, content, pitch)."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Gong creating ‘Revenue Intelligence’.",
"Superhuman creating ‘Premium Email Experience’.",
"Notion focusing on ‘All-in-One Workspace’."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Subcategory too niche.",
"Poor naming that confuses buyers.",
"Positioning that does not align with product experience."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Category keyword growth.",
"Brand → category association.",
"Inbound lead relevance."
]
},
{
"name": "Anti-Competitor Positioning (Law of Opposites + Exclusivity)",
"related_framework": "Law of Exclusivity + Law of Opposites",
"use_case": "Startup needs to stand out against a dominant competitor.",
"steps": [
"Study competitor’s word/position deeply.",
"Choose a contrasting attribute customers want.",
"Frame the competitor’s strength as a weakness.",
"Build messaging that exaggerates the contrast.",
"Embed contrast in visuals, messaging, and feature priorities."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Basecamp: ‘We’re simple’ vs enterprise project management tools.",
"Pepsi: ‘Young and new’ vs Coke’s nostalgic image.",
"Dyson: ‘Engineered differently’ vs generic vacuum brands."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Being opposite in ways customers don’t care about.",
"Weak or arbitrary contrast.",
"Attacking without offering a better alternative."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Competitor-switch reasons in win/loss analysis.",
"Differentiation score in surveys.",
"Share of voice compared to category leaders."
]
}
]
}

{
"title": "Building a StoryBrand",
"author": "Donald Miller",
"category": "Marketing / Messaging / Storytelling",
"tags": ["storytelling", "brand messaging", "marketing clarity", "narrative design", "customer-centric"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "Brands grow when they stop making themselves the hero and instead position themselves as the guide that helps the customer (the true hero) overcome a problem and achieve success. Clear messaging wins; confusing messaging loses.",
"problem_statement": "Most startup messaging is vague, self-centered, and confusing. When customers cannot understand what you do within 5 seconds, they leave. Without a clear narrative, leads don't convert.",
"target_audience": "Founders, marketers, product teams, GTM leaders, storytellers, anyone writing websites or pitch decks.",
"promised_transformation": "A repeatable 7-part narrative framework (StoryBrand) to craft ultra-clear messaging that positions your customer as the hero and your company as the guide.",
"key_ideas": [
"The customer is the hero, not your brand.",
"A clear story beats clever marketing.",
"Communicate what you do in the simplest possible language.",
"Customers are drawn to brands that help them survive and thrive.",
"The StoryBrand framework: Character → Problem → Guide → Plan → Call to Action → Avoid Failure → Achieve Success.",
"Every brand must clearly state: what you offer, how it makes life better, and what the customer must do next.",
"Your website must pass the 5-second clarity test."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "The StoryBrand 7-Part Framework (SB7)",
"type": "framework",
"description": "A storytelling structure that positions customers as heroes and brands as guides.",
"components": [
"1. Character (the hero = your customer)",
"2. Problem (external, internal, philosophical)",
"3. Guide (your brand with empathy + authority)",
"4. Plan (simple, actionable steps)",
"5. Call to Action (direct + transitional)",
"6. Failure (what’s at stake if they don’t act)",
"7. Success (the transformation they desire)"
],
"when_it_applies": "Homepage messaging, pitch decks, ads, onboarding, content.",
"limitations": "Overuse can make messaging feel formulaic if not adapted thoughtfully."
},
{
"name": "Customer-as-Hero Principle",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Brands grow when they stop positioning themselves as heroes and instead help customers succeed.",
"components": [
"Hero = customer",
"Guide = brand",
"Problem = villain",
"Success = customer transformation"
],
"when_it_applies": "All marketing communication.",
"limitations": "Founders often struggle to reduce self-focus."
},
{
"name": "The Three Levels of Problems",
"type": "model",
"description": "Customers experience three layers of pain; speaking to all three creates deeper resonance.",
"components": [
"External Problem (surface-level struggle)",
"Internal Problem (emotional frustration)",
"Philosophical Problem (why this shouldn’t be happening)"
],
"when_it_applies": "Copywriting, ads, storytelling.",
"limitations": "Philosophical messaging must be subtle; overuse feels preachy."
},
{
"name": "The Guide Positioning (Empathy + Authority)",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Your role is to guide the customer, using empathy and authority to build trust.",
"components": [
"Empathy (we understand your struggle)",
"Authority (proof, testimonials, credentials)",
"Plan (simple steps to follow)",
"Support (risk reversal, success path)"
],
"when_it_applies": "Sales calls, websites, onboarding.",
"limitations": "Too much authority becomes arrogance."
},
{
"name": "The Call to Action Structure",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Every brand needs both direct and transitional CTAs to move customers through the buying journey.",
"components": [
"Direct CTA (buy now, book a call, start trial)",
"Transitional CTA (lead magnet, newsletter, webinar)"
],
"when_it_applies": "Funnels, landing pages, ads.",
"limitations": "Confusing or multiple CTAs reduce conversions."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Building Your StoryBrand Script (SB7)",
"related_framework": "StoryBrand 7-Part Framework",
"use_case": "Startup needs clear foundational messaging for website and sales.",
"steps": [
"Define your hero (customer) as specifically as possible.",
"Identify the hero’s external problem (e.g., slow workflows).",
"Define the internal problem (frustration, overwhelm).",
"Write the philosophical ‘why it matters’ message.",
"Position your brand as the guide: show empathy and authority.",
"Create a simple 3-step plan (Plan A).",
"Define your direct and transitional CTAs.",
"Describe the failure your product helps them avoid.",
"Describe the success your product enables.",
"Combine all elements into a StoryBrand BrandScript."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"AI bookkeeping: ‘Stop drowning in messy spreadsheets. Automate your books and get peace of mind (Success).’",
"B2B SaaS: ‘You deserve ops tools that work for you — not against you.’"
],
"failure_modes": [
"Positioning brand as the hero.",
"Plan with too many steps.",
"Missing emotional layer (internal problem).",
"Abstract success without concrete outcomes."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Website clarity score.",
"Bounce rate reduction after clarity rewrite.",
"CTA click-through rates.",
"Lead quality improvement."
]
},
{
"name": "Creating a Clear, Story-Based Homepage",
"related_framework": "Customer-as-Hero Principle",
"use_case": "Startup wants homepage messaging that converts quickly.",
"steps": [
"Headline states the benefit in 5 seconds.",
"Subheadline clarifies what you offer + who it’s for.",
"Define the problem the customer faces.",
"Position your brand as the guide with empathy.",
"Show a simple step-by-step plan.",
"Use strong direct CTA in header.",
"Add transitional CTA for lower-intent visitors.",
"Show before-after transformation (visual or textual).",
"Remove anything that adds cognitive load."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Calendly: ‘Easy scheduling ahead.’",
"Shopify: ‘The platform commerce is built on.’",
"Notion: ‘Write, plan, and get organized — in one place.’"
],
"failure_modes": [
"Too many CTAs.",
"Fancy language instead of clarity.",
"Talking about the company instead of the customer.",
"Long paragraphs that overwhelm users."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Homepage conversion rate.",
"Average scroll depth.",
"First 5-second impression test.",
"Hero-section CTA CTR."
]
},
{
"name": "Story-Led Sales Calls",
"related_framework": "Guide Positioning",
"use_case": "AE or founder wants to run high-converting discovery + demo calls.",
"steps": [
"Start with hero framing: 'What’s the main challenge that brought you here today?'",
"Identify external + internal problems through SPIN-style questioning.",
"Position yourself as guide by sharing a story of someone similar.",
"Explain your plan in 2–3 simple steps.",
"Show the transformation using before/after stories.",
"Present CTA as the natural next step.",
"Frame failure (risk of inaction) subtly.",
"End with a clear path (‘Here’s what the next 7 days look like’)."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"‘A founder like you reduced ops time by 60% after implementing this…’",
"‘Teams using us now onboard 3× faster.’"
],
"failure_modes": [
"Selling too early.",
"Overloading with features.",
"No story or emotional connection.",
"Not ending with a clear CTA."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Discovery → demo conversion.",
"Demo → proposal conversion.",
"Sales cycle length.",
"Customer understanding score (via follow-up surveys)."
]
}
]
}

{
"title": "Influence: The Psychology of Persuasion",
"author": "Robert Cialdini",
"category": "Marketing / Sales Psychology / Behavioral Science",
"tags": ["persuasion", "psychology", "behavioral science", "sales", "marketing", "Cialdini Principles"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "Human decisions — in marketing, sales, and everyday life — follow predictable psychological principles. When used ethically, these principles dramatically increase conversions, trust, and compliance.",
"problem_statement": "Founders often rely on logical arguments or product features, ignoring the psychological triggers that actually drive decision-making. This leads to weak messaging, low conversions, and ineffective persuasion.",
"target_audience": "Founders, sales teams, marketers, copywriters, product designers, growth teams.",
"promised_transformation": "A powerful set of seven persuasion principles — Reciprocity, Commitment/Consistency, Social Proof, Authority, Liking, Scarcity, and Unity — that can be engineered into marketing, product, and sales systems.",
"key_ideas": [
"People rely on psychological shortcuts; persuasion happens most at a subconscious level.",
"Reciprocity triggers a natural desire to return favors.",
"Commitment & Consistency make people stick to past statements and behaviors.",
"Social Proof reduces uncertainty through collective validation.",
"Authority increases trust and compliance.",
"Liking makes people say yes to those they feel connected to.",
"Scarcity increases perceived value and action.",
"Unity (added in later editions) triggers belonging and identity-based trust.",
"Ethical persuasion creates long-term trust; manipulation destroys it."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "The 7 Principles of Influence",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Cialdini’s universal psychological triggers that shape human decisions.",
"components": [
"Reciprocity",
"Commitment & Consistency",
"Social Proof",
"Authority",
"Liking",
"Scarcity",
"Unity"
],
"when_it_applies": "Marketing, landing pages, sales calls, product UX, onboarding.",
"limitations": "Must be used ethically; misuse damages trust."
},
{
"name": "Reciprocity",
"type": "principle",
"description": "When someone receives something, they feel compelled to return the favor.",
"components": [
"Genuine value first",
"Lead magnets",
"Samples",
"Personalized help",
"Over-delivery"
],
"when_it_applies": "Lead generation, cold outreach, onboarding.",
"limitations": "Attempts at forced reciprocity feel manipulative."
},
{
"name": "Commitment & Consistency",
"type": "principle",
"description": "People want to stay consistent with their previous statements, beliefs, and actions.",
"components": [
"Micro-commitments",
"Onboarding streaks",
"Public statements",
"Agreed goals",
"Surveys that prime desired behavior"
],
"when_it_applies": "Funnels, onboarding, sales calls.",
"limitations": "If commitments are too large upfront, people resist."
},
{
"name": "Social Proof",
"type": "principle",
"description": "People look to others — especially similar others — when uncertain.",
"components": [
"Testimonials",
"Case studies",
"User numbers",
"Industry badges",
"Community presence"
],
"when_it_applies": "Landing pages, ads, sales decks.",
"limitations": "Fake or weak social proof backfires."
},
{
"name": "Authority",
"type": "principle",
"description": "People trust credible experts and signals of competence.",
"components": [
"Credentials",
"Media features",
"Third-party endorsements",
"Data",
"Awards",
"Certifications"
],
"when_it_applies": "Sales calls, high-ticket programs, B2B SaaS.",
"limitations": "Overuse appears arrogant."
},
{
"name": "Liking",
"type": "principle",
"description": "We say yes to people we like — similarity, compliments, familiarity increase compliance.",
"components": [
"Relatability",
"Rapport building",
"Shared identity",
"Warm tone"
],
"when_it_applies": "Founder-led sales, community building.",
"limitations": "Fake friendliness is easily detected."
},
{
"name": "Scarcity",
"type": "principle",
"description": "People want more of what is less available.",
"components": [
"Limited seats",
"Limited-time offers",
"Exclusive access",
"Rare bonuses"
],
"when_it_applies": "Cohort-based programs, launches, waitlists.",
"limitations": "Fake scarcity kills credibility."
},
{
"name": "Unity",
"type": "principle",
"description": "People trust and comply with those they see as part of their identity group.",
"components": [
"Shared values",
"Shared struggles",
"Community identity",
"Tribe building"
],
"when_it_applies": "Communities, social brands, cause-driven companies.",
"limitations": "Must be authentic; cannot fake belonging."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Applying the 7 Principles to a Landing Page",
"related_framework": "The 7 Principles of Influence",
"use_case": "Increase landing page conversions through psychology-backed messaging.",
"steps": [
"Add a high-value lead magnet to trigger Reciprocity.",
"Include micro-commitments (email input, small quiz).",
"Add Social Proof near CTAs (logos, testimonials, case studies).",
"Show Authority through credentials, awards, or expert quotes.",
"Use Liking: personal founder photo, relatable story.",
"Use Scarcity ethically (cohort start dates, limited seats).",
"Reinforce Unity through community language (‘For first-time founders…’)."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Founder program website: testimonials from similar founders + cohort scarcity.",
"SaaS landing page: ‘Used by 3,000 startup teams’ + micro-commit signup."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Fake scarcity.",
"Low-quality testimonials.",
"Over-emphasizing authority (comes off as bragging).",
"Too many commitments too early."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Lead conversion rate.",
"Scroll depth to CTA.",
"CTA CTR.",
"Lead quality score."
]
},
{
"name": "Using Influence Principles in Sales Calls",
"related_framework": "Commitment & Consistency + Authority + Social Proof",
"use_case": "Improve discovery → close rates in founder-led or AE-led sales.",
"steps": [
"Build rapport (Liking).",
"Ask alignment questions that create small commitments (‘Is this a priority for you?’).",
"Share a short credibility story (Authority).",
"Bring Social Proof: similar customer wins.",
"Guide prospect through their own words (Consistency).",
"Introduce time/seat constraints (Scarcity).",
"Close with a clear and confident CTA."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"‘Founders like you typically see ROI within 30 days…’",
"‘We only take 20 startups per cohort to maintain depth of mentorship.’"
],
"failure_modes": [
"Overloading with authority too early.",
"Pressure-based scarcity.",
"Generic or irrelevant social proof.",
"Skipping micro-commitments."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Discovery-to-demo conversion.",
"Demo-to-close conversion.",
"Number of micro-commitments achieved.",
"Objection frequency."
]
},
{
"name": "Engineering Virality & Sharing Through Social Proof + Unity",
"related_framework": "Social Proof + Unity",
"use_case": "Design a product or community that spreads by itself.",
"steps": [
"Highlight stories of people ‘like the user’ succeeding.",
"Create identity-based communities (‘Founder Tribe’, ‘AI Builders Club’).",
"Feature members publicly (profiles, wins, shoutouts).",
"Use community rituals (weekly calls, milestones).",
"Give sharable assets (templates, certificates, badges).",
"Reward collaboration and referrals.",
"Create 'others like me use this' triggers across UX."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Slack’s ‘channels’ reinforcing teamwork identity.",
"Duolingo’s public streaks (unity + social proof)."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Forcing community through Discord/WhatsApp with no rituals.",
"Low-quality social proof.",
"Irrelevant tribe identity.",
"No ongoing engagement loops."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Referral rate.",
"Community retention.",
"Organic mentions.",
"User-generated content volume."
]
}
]
}

{
"title": "Ogilvy on Advertising",
"author": "David Ogilvy",
"category": "Marketing / Advertising / Copywriting",
"tags": ["advertising", "creative strategy", "branding", "copywriting", "consumer psychology"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "Great advertising is not about creativity for its own sake — it is about selling. The ads that work are the ones grounded in research, clarity, storytelling, strong headlines, and deep understanding of consumers.",
"problem_statement": "Most advertising is ineffective because it is built for awards, ego, and aesthetics rather than true persuasion. Marketers ignore research, put cleverness over clarity, and fail to understand customers.",
"target_audience": "Marketers, founders, advertisers, copywriters, creative directors, brand strategists, D2C entrepreneurs.",

"key_ideas": [
"The purpose of advertising is to sell — not entertain.",
"Headlines are the most important element; 80% of people only read the headline.",
"Research and consumer insight precede great creative work.",
"Brand image must be consistent and distinct.",
"Long copy works when it is interesting — consumers read what interests them.",
"Test everything: visuals, headlines, body copy, offers.",
"Storytelling and emotional resonance matter more than cleverness.",
"Never talk down to your audience."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [

"2. The consumer is not an idiot — she is your wife.",
"3. Headlines matter more than everything else.",
"4. Position the product clearly and consistently.",
"5. Use storytelling and emotional hooks.",
"6. Test all elements rigorously.",
"7. Maintain long-term brand image."

"when_it_applies": "Ads, landing pages, creative strategy, campaigns.",

"Specificity.",
"Emotional hooks.",
"Curiosity without clickbait."
],
"when_it_applies": "Landing pages, ads, LinkedIn posts, email subject lines.",

},
{

"Visual identity",

},
{

"related_framework": "Ogilvy’s 7 Rules of Advertising",

"Copy comprehension score"

},
{

"metrics_to_track": [

"Visual identity consistency (design audit)",

"Customer perception surveys"
]
}
]
}

{
"title": "Breakthrough Advertising",
"author": "Eugene M. Schwartz",
"category": "Marketing / Copywriting / Market Sophistication",
"tags": ["copywriting", "market sophistication", "customer awareness", "mass desire", "headline strategy", "direct response"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "You cannot create desire — you can only channel and direct desires that already exist in the market. The effectiveness of your advertising depends on how precisely your message matches the market’s existing level of awareness and sophistication about the problem and the solution.",
"problem_statement": "Most advertising fails because it ignores the maturity of the market. It either speaks too simply to a sophisticated audience or too complexly to an unaware one, pushing claims that don’t match what the prospect is ready to hear.",
"target_audience": "Direct-response marketers, copywriters, founders, growth leads, performance marketers, advanced GTM strategists.",
"promised_transformation": "A structured way to craft copy, offers, and campaigns that align with the prospect’s stage of awareness and the market’s level of sophistication, so your message feels inevitable rather than forced.",
"key_ideas": [
"You do not create desire; desire already exists. Your job is to channel it toward your product.",
"Every market passes through levels of sophistication: from simple claims to complex mechanisms.",
"Prospects move through levels of awareness: from unaware to fully aware and ready to buy.",
"Advertising must match both: awareness (of problem/solution) and sophistication (of existing claims in the market).",
"Headlines and leads carry most of the burden — they must meet the reader exactly where they are mentally.",
"As markets mature, claims must shift: from bold promises to unique mechanisms, proof, and deeper emotional resonance.",
"Effective copy leverages mass desires ethically rather than trying to invent new ones.",
"The structure and intensity of your copy must reflect the maturity and skepticism of your audience."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "Levels of Market Sophistication",
"type": "framework",
"description": "A model describing how markets evolve as more competitors and stronger claims enter. Each level demands different copy and angles.",
"components": [
"Level 1: The first entrant makes a simple, direct claim about the main benefit.",
"Level 2: Competitors enter and escalate the claim (more, faster, cheaper).",
"Level 3: Market becomes jaded; copy must introduce a new mechanism — the unique way the product works.",
"Level 4: Mechanisms and claims are now crowded; copy must dramatize benefits, proof, and differentiation with depth.",
"Level 5: Market is saturated; copy must shift to deeper emotional, identity, or long-term transformation narratives, often reframing the category."
],
"when_it_applies": "Any crowded or emerging market where multiple solutions already exist (e.g., SaaS categories, fitness, money-making, productivity).",
"limitations": "If taken literally, it can tempt marketers to escalate claims beyond what is truthful; must be grounded in real results and proof."
},
{
"name": "Stages of Customer Awareness",
"type": "framework",
"description": "A progression of how aware a prospect is about their problem, possible solutions, and your specific product.",
"components": [
"Most Aware: Knows your product and just needs the right offer.",
"Product-Aware: Knows your product but not sure if it’s right for them.",
"Solution-Aware: Knows solutions exist but not yours specifically.",
"Problem-Aware: Feels the problem but doesn’t know solutions.",
"Completely Unaware: No conscious recognition of the problem or solution."
],
"when_it_applies": "Segmentation, funnel design, messaging by channel (retargeting vs cold, search vs social).",
"limitations": "Over-simplifying audiences into one awareness level can misfire; segments can span multiple levels."
},
{
"name": "Mass Desire Theory",
"type": "model",
"description": "Markets are built upon large, pre-existing desires (health, wealth, status, love, security, convenience). Advertising channels those desires toward a specific product by promising a focused, believable satisfaction of that desire.",
"components": [
"Identify mass desire relevant to your market.",
"Select one specific dimension of that desire to focus on.",
"Intensify and clarify that desire in your message.",
"Connect your product as the most direct, believable way to fulfill it."
],
"when_it_applies": "Offer creation, positioning, campaign themes, messaging strategy.",
"limitations": "If desire is amplified without care, messaging can slide into fear-mongering or manipulation; must remain respectful and accurate."
},
{
"name": "The Unique Mechanism",
"type": "framework",
"description": "The distinct, named ‘how it works’ behind your product — used especially in more sophisticated markets to stand out from similar offers.",
"components": [
"Name the mechanism (framework, engine, process, method).",
"Explain what it does in simple terms.",
"Connect the mechanism clearly to the main benefit.",
"Show why this mechanism is superior to alternatives.",
"Support with proof (data, case studies, examples)."
],
"when_it_applies": "Crowded categories where similar promises are common; mid to late sophistication stages.",
"limitations": "If the mechanism is just a label without real substance, customers will feel misled."
},
{
"name": "Headline and Lead Architecture",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Headlines and leads must meet the reader at their awareness/sophistication level, promising a specific outcome or mechanism that resonates with their current mental state.",
"components": [
"Match to Awareness: problem-based, solution-based, or product-based headlines.",
"Match to Sophistication: simple claim vs mechanism-driven vs proof-driven.",
"Use of specificity: numbers, timeframes, concrete outcomes.",
"Emotional charge tied to mass desire.",
"Lead expansion: story, scenario, or explanation that fulfills the headline’s promise."
],
"when_it_applies": "Ads, landing pages, sales letters, email subject lines, hero sections.",
"limitations": "Over-claiming or exaggerating destroys trust, especially in sophisticated markets."
},
{
"name": "Channeling vs Creating Desire",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Desire already exists in the market. Your job is not to invent new desires but to show how your product satisfies one better, faster, more safely, or more completely.",
"components": [
"Identify core desires (health, wealth, status, freedom, meaning, security).",
"See how competitors currently channel these desires.",
"Choose a sharper angle on the same desire.",
"Direct that desire toward your unique mechanism and offer."
],
"when_it_applies": "Core value proposition and campaign-level messaging.",
"limitations": "If the desire you choose doesn’t genuinely map to your product, the message will feel hollow or manipulative."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Diagnosing Market Sophistication and Matching Your Copy",
"related_framework": "Levels of Market Sophistication",
"use_case": "A startup wants to avoid generic messaging and instead match its copy to the true maturity of the category.",
"steps": [
"List top 10–20 competitors and analyze their primary promises and headlines.",
"Ask: Are they using simple benefit claims, escalated claims, mechanisms, or deep emotional narratives?",
"Assign a likely sophistication level to your market (1–5).",
"For Level 1–2: focus on clear, strong primary benefit and proof (no over-complication).",
"For Level 3: introduce a clear, named mechanism as the centerpiece of your copy.",
"For Level 4: differentiate via proof depth, case studies, specificity, and richer emotional context.",
"For Level 5: consider reframing the category, focusing on deeper identity or transformation for a specific niche.",
"Rewrite your headline and first 3–4 paragraphs to fit that level rather than generic one-size-fits-all messaging."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"In a young category (Level 1–2), a project management tool emphasizing: ‘Organize all your work in one place.’",
"In a mature CRM market (Level 4–5), a startup focusing on: ‘The only CRM built specifically for founder-led sales — with a proprietary follow-up engine.’"
],
"failure_modes": [
"Treating a Level 4 or 5 market like Level 1 (too naive, ignored).",
"Overcomplicating messaging in a young market that just needs clear benefits.",
"Pretending to have a unique mechanism that is just a relabeled generic feature."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"CTR on top-of-funnel ads for new messaging.",
"Landing page conversion rate after sophistication-based rewrite.",
"Qualitative feedback on “how different” or “how clear” the message feels.",
"Sales call qualitative notes on prospect perception of uniqueness."
]
},
{
"name": "Mapping Campaigns to Awareness Levels",
"related_framework": "Stages of Customer Awareness",
"use_case": "You want your ads, emails, and pages to speak differently to cold vs warm vs hot audiences.",
"steps": [
"Segment your audience by behavior: cold (never seen you), warm (engaged or visited), hot (trial, demo, or past buyers).",
"Map segments to awareness: cold ≈ problem/solution-aware, warm ≈ solution/product-aware, hot ≈ most aware.",
"For Problem-Aware audiences: lead with the pain and category (what’s going wrong; what kind of solution exists).",
"For Solution-Aware audiences: lead with your category and mechanism (why your type of solution is best).",
"For Product-Aware and Most Aware: lead with specific offer, terms, and proof (why now, why this package).",
"Craft separate creatives and landing pages per awareness band.",
"Route traffic accordingly (cold ads → problem/solution pages, retargeting → product/offer pages)."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Cold ad: ‘Struggling to keep your startup finances under control?’ → blog/lead magnet.",
"Retargeting ad: ‘How our AI CFO saves founders 10+ hours/month.’",
"Hot email: ‘Enroll by Sunday and get 1:1 onboarding with your cohort.’"
],
"failure_modes": [
"Sending ‘most aware’ style hard offers to totally cold traffic.",
"Running only one generic page for all traffic sources.",
"Ignoring behavioral signals that shift awareness (e.g., webinar attendance)."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Conversion rate by awareness segment.",
"Time on page and scroll depth per segment.",
"Retargeting ROI vs cold ROI.",
"Lead → customer conversion by entry point."
]
},
{
"name": "Designing a Unique Mechanism and Integrating It into Copy",
"related_framework": "The Unique Mechanism + Channeling vs Creating Desire",
"use_case": "You are in a crowded market and need to stand out without resorting to unrealistic promises.",
"steps": [
"List how your solution actually works — processes, algorithms, workflows, differentiating choices.",
"Identify what is genuinely different about *how* you achieve the result (not just what the result is).",
"Give this mechanism a simple, memorable name (framework, engine, method, system).",
"Write a short explanation connecting: desire → mechanism → outcome.",
"Make the mechanism central in headline, lead, and visuals.",
"Back it with proof — use cases, data, or case studies that show this mechanism at work.",
"Refine messaging so that competitors cannot credibly claim the same mechanism without obviously copying you."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"‘Adaptive Follow-Up Engine’ for a sales tool that sequences follow-up based on behavior.",
"‘Revenue Clarity Map’ for a finance product that visualizes cashflow scenarios.",
"‘Founder Focus Sprint Method’ for a program that combines coaching, accountability, and sprint design."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Naming a mechanism that’s just a generic feature (no real distinction).",
"Using jargon-heavy or confusing names.",
"Forgetting to tie the mechanism back to a concrete, valued outcome."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Prospect recall of mechanism name after calls.",
"Usage of mechanism language by customers in reviews or referrals.",
"Differentiation score in win/loss interviews.",
"Improvement in win rate in competitive deals."
]
}
]
}

{
"title": "This Is Marketing",
"author": "Seth Godin",
"category": "Marketing / Branding / Modern GTM",
"tags": ["marketing", "branding", "trust", "storytelling", "positioning", "minimum viable audience"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "Marketing is the act of making change happen by serving a specific audience, earning their trust, and solving their real problems. You don’t need mass appeal; you need to matter deeply to a small group first.",
"problem_statement": "Most founders and marketers think marketing is about attention, virality, or manipulation — loudly promoting rather than quietly serving. This leads to shallow tactics that fail to build long-term trust.",
"target_audience": "Founders, marketers, creators, brand strategists, community builders, coaches, anyone building something for humans.",
"promised_transformation": "A worldview shift: from chasing attention to earning trust; from selling to serving; from trying to reach everyone to meaningfully impacting a small, specific group first.",
"key_ideas": [
"Marketing is about solving problems and creating change — not shouting.",
"You cannot be for everyone; choose a Minimum Viable Audience (MVA).",
"People don’t buy products — they buy feelings, identity, and belonging.",
"Trust is earned over time through consistency, empathy, and generosity.",
"Effective marketing tells a true story about the change your product creates.",
"Status, identity, and affiliation are core drivers of human behavior.",
"Tension and forward motion (a gap between ‘before’ and ‘after’) motivate action.",
"Remarkable products spread because people talk about them voluntarily.",
"Permission marketing: earn attention, don’t interrupt to steal it."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "Minimum Viable Audience (MVA)",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Instead of trying to reach everyone, find the smallest group of people for whom your product can create meaningful change — and serve them deeply.",
"components": [
"Identify the smallest viable group.",
"Understand their worldview.",
"Serve them so well they tell others.",
"Build trust and narrative inside the tribe."
],
"when_it_applies": "Early-stage startups, niche markets, community-driven products, creator brands.",
"limitations": "Founders often resist narrowing down; requires discipline and patience."
},
{
"name": "The Marketing Triangle (Story → Tension → Change)",
"type": "model",
"description": "A narrative structure showing how humans are moved to act.",
"components": [
"Story: a narrative people can believe.",
"Tension: the gap between their current state and desired future.",
"Change: the transformation your product enables."
],
"when_it_applies": "Website messaging, storytelling, brand building, pitch decks.",
"limitations": "Tension must be ethical — no fear-mongering or false urgency."
},
{
"name": "Positioning Through Worldview",
"type": "principle",
"description": "People buy according to their worldview, not your features. Aligning with worldview builds trust.",
"components": [
"Identity",
"Values",
"Beliefs",
"Aspirations",
"Struggles"
],
"when_it_applies": "Brand building, community design, segmentation.",
"limitations": "Misreading worldview leads to mismatched messaging."
},
{
"name": "Status Dynamics",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Humans act to protect or improve their status within their groups. Marketing often speaks to these silent motivations.",
"components": [
"Affiliation (belonging)",
"Dominance (status gain)",
"Insecurity (status threat)",
"Identity expression",
"Social norms"
],
"when_it_applies": "Brand positioning, messaging, pricing, luxury/aspirational products.",
"limitations": "Status-based messaging must be subtle and respectful."
},
{
"name": "The Trust-Building Loop",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Trust is built gradually by aligning empathy, promises, and delivery.",
"components": [
"Empathy → Understand their story and worldview",
"Relevance → Show how your product fits their needs",
"Consistency → Keep your promises repeatedly",
"Permission → Earn the right to communicate",
"Advocacy → Users spread the story voluntarily"
],
"when_it_applies": "Brand building, email marketing, onboarding, cohort programs.",
"limitations": "Trust building is slow; requires long-term consistency."
},
{
"name": "The Purple Cow Principle",
"type": "framework",
"description": "People talk about things that are remarkable — things worth making a remark about.",
"components": [
"Novelty",
"Bold positioning",
"Unexpected delight",
"Unique perspective",
"Exceptional experience"
],
"when_it_applies": "GTM, product design, founder-led brands, viral loops.",
"limitations": "Remarkability must reflect true product value, not gimmicks."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Defining Your Minimum Viable Audience (MVA)",
"related_framework": "Minimum Viable Audience (MVA)",
"use_case": "A founder wants to choose a niche and avoid watered-down messaging.",
"steps": [
"List all potential customer segments.",
"Identify which segment has the strongest pain and motivation.",
"Look for people who share a common worldview (identity, values).",
"Choose the segment where you can create *disproportionate* transformation.",
"Interview 5–10 people from that segment.",
"Craft messaging centered around their language, not yours.",
"Validate by testing a small, high-intimacy offer with the MVA."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"AI bookkeeping for solo founders earning ₹3–10 lakhs/month.",
"CRM built specifically for founder-led early sales.",
"Marketing playbook for female solopreneurs restarting careers."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Choosing an audience too broad (‘any startup’).",
"Choosing an audience with weak urgency.",
"Ignoring worldview — targeting audiences with conflicting values.",
"Building for yourself instead of the tribe."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Segment penetration rate.",
"Conversion rate within the MVA.",
"Referral rate inside the niche.",
"Retention and advocacy among early users."
]
},
{
"name": "Crafting a Story-Led Marketing Narrative",
"related_framework": "Marketing Triangle (Story → Tension → Change)",
"use_case": "Startup wants messaging that resonates emotionally and strategically.",
"steps": [
"Identify the existing story your audience tells themselves.",
"Define the tension — the pain, gap, or aspiration unmet.",
"Articulate the change your product enables.",
"Express the transformation in human language.",
"Embed identity and worldview signals.",
"Use simple, clear sentences that pass the 5-second test.",
"Test narrative with 3–5 ideal audience members.",
"Refine based on emotional resonance, not logic alone."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"‘You started your startup for freedom — not to drown in operations.’",
"‘You deserve tools as fast and ambitious as you are.’"
],
"failure_modes": [
"Telling your story instead of theirs.",
"Over-explaining the product before establishing emotional tension.",
"Using complex or jargon-filled language.",
"No clear ‘after’ picture."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Message recall rate.",
"Bounce rate of story-driven sections.",
"Emotional resonance in user interviews.",
"Click-through rate on narrative CTAs."
]
},
{
"name": "Building a Trust-First Funnel",
"related_framework": "Trust-Building Loop",
"use_case": "A founder wants to create a funnel that converts without pressure tactics.",
"steps": [
"Create high-value content that genuinely helps (Reciprocity).",
"Show understanding of the user's worldview (Empathy).",
"Send consistent, permission-based communication (No spam).",
"Introduce the product as a natural extension of the trust built.",
"Provide risk reversal (guarantees, transparency, social proof).",
"Demonstrate results through stories and case studies.",
"Invite action through a soft but clear CTA."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"A 5-day value email series for early-stage founders.",
"Weekly community calls showing transformation stories.",
"Building a library of templates that solve real pains."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Aggressive selling too soon.",
"Spammy frequency without permission.",
"Inconsistent delivery that erodes trust.",
"Generic content that doesn't speak to worldview."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Email open rates.",
"Reply and engagement rates.",
"Lead → customer conversion rate.",
"Refund rate (indicator of trust quality)."
]
}
]
}

{
"title": "Principles",
"author": "Ray Dalio",
"category": "Leadership / Decision-Making / Systems Thinking",
"tags": ["principles", "decision-making", "systems", "radical transparency", "life principles", "work principles"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "Success in life and work can be systematized through clear, teachable principles. When you identify the patterns behind good decisions and failures, you can build algorithms that consistently produce better outcomes.",
"problem_statement": "Most people make decisions emotionally or inconsistently, repeating avoidable mistakes. Organizations stagnate due to politics, ego, misalignment, and lack of clear processes.",
"target_audience": "Founders, leaders, operators, managers, systems thinkers, people seeking structured personal and organizational decision-making.",
"promised_transformation": "The ability to make clear, logical decisions by using transparent principles, building feedback-rich systems, and leveraging radical truth and radical transparency.",
"key_ideas": [
"Principles are algorithms for life — once defined, they create consistent decisions.",
"Radical truth and radical transparency remove politics and miscommunication.",
"Organizations must be meritocracies of ideas, not power or hierarchy.",
"Pain + Reflection = Progress.",
"Understand reality objectively and deal with it.",
"Use believability-weighted decision-making.",
"Systemize everything important — don’t rely on memory or emotion.",
"Identify your blind spots through open debate and feedback.",
"People Differences (thinking styles) must be mapped and understood."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "The 5-Step Process for Achieving Goals",
"type": "framework",
"description": "A looping system for continuous improvement and achieving meaningful objectives.",
"components": [
"1. Set clear goals.",
"2. Identify problems preventing achievement of those goals.",
"3. Diagnose problems at the root cause level.",
"4. Design solutions and systems.",
"5. Execute with discipline and track results."
],
"when_it_applies": "Goal setting, strategic planning, OKRs, operations.",
"limitations": "Requires brutal honesty and willingness to face personal weaknesses."
},
{
"name": "Radical Truth & Radical Transparency",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Open, honest communication and transparency across an organization to reduce politics and increase clarity.",
"components": [
"Truth-oriented communication.",
"Recording meetings and allowing access.",
"Open disagreement.",
"Feedback loops from all directions.",
"Visible decision-making processes."
],
"when_it_applies": "Team culture, hiring, leadership, conflict resolution.",
"limitations": "Can be emotionally overwhelming for people unused to direct feedback."
},
{
"name": "Believability-Weighted Decision Making",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Weight opinions based on track record and domain expertise instead of hierarchy.",
"components": [
"Define believability criteria.",
"Map who has demonstrated performance.",
"Give stronger weight to credible voices.",
"Document decision rationales."
],
"when_it_applies": "Leadership meetings, strategy decisions, investment decisions.",
"limitations": "Requires accurate measurement of competence; can create elitism if mishandled."
},
{
"name": "Pain + Reflection = Progress",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Negative emotions indicate areas requiring growth; reflection converts pain into learning.",
"components": [
"Embrace discomfort.",
"Identify truth without ego.",
"Reflect systematically.",
"Write principles based on insights."
],
"when_it_applies": "Failure analysis, performance reviews, personal growth.",
"limitations": "Requires emotional maturity and self-awareness."
},
{
"name": "People Are Wired Differently",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Understanding thinking styles and personality differences improves collaboration.",
"components": [
"Cognitive profiles.",
"Strength-based roles.",
"Dot collectors for feedback.",
"Psychometric tools (MBTI, Big 5, etc.)."
],
"when_it_applies": "Hiring, team design, conflict management.",
"limitations": "Labels can oversimplify nuanced individuals."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Implementing the 5-Step System for Founders",
"related_framework": "The 5-Step Process for Achieving Goals",
"use_case": "A founder wants a repeatable process for achieving OKRs and personal goals.",
"steps": [
"Define measurable quarterly goals.",
"List obstacles immediately stopping progress.",
"Ask: ‘What patterns cause these obstacles?’",
"Create systems and schedules to remove patterns.",
"Track progress weekly with metrics.",
"Redesign as you encounter new problems."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Engineering OKRs using weekly sprint reviews.",
"Marketing goals broken into systems: content → distribution → analytics."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Setting vague goals.",
"Diagnosing symptoms instead of root causes.",
"Failure to execute consistently."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Weekly goal progress.",
"Obstacle resolution rate.",
"Execution consistency score."
]
},
{
"name": "Running a Believability-Weighted Meeting",
"related_framework": "Believability-Weighted Decision Making",
"use_case": "A team wants to avoid debates where loudest wins.",
"steps": [
"Define decision topic.",
"Identify participants with belief scores.",
"Collect structured opinions.",
"Weight votes based on believability.",
"Record final decision and reasoning."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Technical strategy weighted toward senior engineers.",
"Pricing strategy weighted toward sales + finance."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Using hierarchy instead of believability.",
"Ignoring dissent from less-experienced but insightful voices."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Decision quality score.",
"Time saved in meetings.",
"Post-decision performance outcomes."
]
}
]
}

{
"title": "Think Again",
"author": "Adam Grant",
"category": "Mindset / Cognitive Flexibility / Leadership",
"tags": ["rethinking", "mental models", "leadership", "cognitive biases", "learning mindset", "intellectual humility"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "The ability to rethink — to update beliefs, unlearn outdated assumptions, and stay mentally flexible — is a superpower for individuals and organizations in a rapidly changing world.",
"problem_statement": "People cling to outdated beliefs due to ego, identity, and cognitive biases. This leads to poor judgment, slow learning, and reactivity instead of adaptability.",
"target_audience": "Leaders, founders, innovators, educators, product builders, anyone wanting sharper thinking.",
"promised_transformation": "A mindset and toolkit for rethinking beliefs, embracing intellectual humility, debating constructively, and building cultures that constantly question assumptions.",
"key_ideas": [
"We must spend more time thinking again than thinking the same thing harder.",
"Most people get stuck in ‘Preacher, Prosecutor, and Politician’ modes, defending ego instead of seeking truth.",
"The ‘Scientist Mode’ — experimenting, questioning, testing — leads to better decisions.",
"Confidence + Humility = Optimal reasoning.",
"Identity should be tied to values, not rigid beliefs.",
"Good disagreements accelerate learning.",
"Psychological safety enables open rethinking.",
"Organizations must reward learning over stubbornness.",
"Rethinking is a skill that compounds over time."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "The 4 Modes of Thinking",

"description": "Human reasoning styles that impact decision-making quality.",
"components": [

"Prosecutor → attacking others' arguments.",
"Politician → seeking approval and alignment.",
"Scientist → forming hypotheses, testing, learning, iterating."
],
"when_it_applies": "Leadership, hiring, strategy, conflict resolution.",
"limitations": "Not all situations allow for scientific exploration (e.g., crises)."
},
{
"name": "The Rethinking Cycle",
"type": "model",
"description": "A mental loop that reinforces continuous learning.",
"components": [
"Doubt → Curiosity → Discovery → Update.",
"Confidence tempered by humility.",
"Identity anchored to being a learner."
],
"when_it_applies": "Product pivots, retros, personal growth.",
"limitations": "Too much doubt can create paralysis."
},
{
"name": "The Good Conflict Framework",
"type": "framework",
"description": "A model for healthy debates that produce better outcomes.",
"components": [
"Attack ideas, not people.",
"Invite strong counterarguments.",
"Use ‘complexity reminders’ — acknowledge uncertainty.",
"Praise successful rethinking.",
"Focus on collective learning, not winning."
],
"when_it_applies": "Team meetings, debates, leadership alignment.",
"limitations": "Requires psychological safety and emotional maturity."
},
{
"name": "Imposter vs Armchair Expert Curve",

"Mount Stupid → Overconfidence peak.",
"Valley of humility.",
"Expert confidence with uncertainty."

"when_it_applies": "Self-assessment, leadership, delegation.",
"limitations": "People can oscillate between stages."
},
{
"name": "Motivational Interviewing for Behavioral Change",
"type": "framework",
"description": "A method to help others rethink without resistance.",
"components": [
"Ask open questions.",
"Listen reflectively.",
"Highlight inconsistencies.",
"Express empathy.",
"Autonomy: let them choose their conclusion."
],
"when_it_applies": "Coaching, mentorship, leadership, negotiations.",

],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [

"Run ‘challenge sessions’ where strategies are questioned openly.",

"Normalize saying ‘I might be wrong.’"

{

{
"title": "The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People",
"author": "Stephen R. Covey",

"tags": ["habits", "leadership", "character ethics", "principle-centered", "effectiveness", "interpersonal skills"],

"problem_statement": "People chase shortcuts, tactics, and surface-level hacks for success instead of building deep character and principle-centered habits that create lasting change.",
"target_audience": "Founders, leaders, creators, parents, managers, anyone seeking long-term effectiveness and relationship mastery.",

"Habits form the bridge between values and results.",
"Effectiveness depends on aligning what you *do* with who you *are*.",
"Win-win thinking, listening empathically, and synergizing create high-trust relationships.",
"The ability to renew yourself physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually sustains long-term performance."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "The 7 Habits Framework",

"Habit 2: Begin with the End in Mind (vision).",
"Habit 3: Put First Things First (prioritization + execution).",
"Habit 4: Think Win-Win (mutual benefit).",
"Habit 5: Seek First to Understand, Then to Be Understood (empathy).",

"Habit 7: Sharpen the Saw (renewal)."

"when_it_applies": "Personal growth, team leadership, conflict resolution, strategy, long-term planning.",

"name": "Circle of Concern vs Circle of Influence",
"type": "model",
"description": "Distinguishes between things you worry about and things you can actually change—focusing on influence increases agency.",
"components": [
"Circle of Concern: things you care about but can't control.",
"Circle of Influence: things you can directly affect.",
"Proactive people expand influence; reactive people shrink it."
],
"when_it_applies": "Stress management, leadership clarity, decision-making.",
"limitations": "Over-focusing on influence can blind you to legitimate external risks."
},
{
"name": "Personal Mission Statement",
"type": "principle",
"description": "A clear articulation of your long-term values, roles, and direction.",

"Visualize your ideal outcomes.",
"Write a statement guiding decisions and actions."
],
"when_it_applies": "Life planning, career decisions, leadership identity.",

},
{
"name": "Time Management Matrix (Eisenhower + Covey)",
"type": "framework",
"description": "A 2×2 matrix dividing activities by urgency and importance, emphasizing Quadrant II (important, not urgent).",
"components": [
"Q1: Important + Urgent (crises).",
"Q2: Important + Not Urgent (strategy, planning, learning).",
"Q3: Not Important + Urgent (distractions).",
"Q4: Not Important + Not Urgent (time-wasters)."
],
"when_it_applies": "Prioritization, weekly planning, leadership focus.",
"limitations": "People often misunderstand 'importance' and misclassify tasks."
},
{
"name": "Emotional Bank Account",

"description": "A metaphor for trust in relationships—every interaction is a deposit or withdrawal.",

"Withdrawals: criticism, disrespect, broken promises.",

],
"when_it_applies": "Leadership, team culture, marriage, partnerships.",
"limitations": "A high balance cannot compensate for acute betrayals."
},
{
"name": "The Maturity Continuum",
"type": "principle",
"description": "A path from dependence → independence → interdependence.",
"components": [
"Dependence (You take care of me).",
"Independence (I take care of myself).",
"Interdependence (We build together and amplify each other)."

"when_it_applies": "Leadership development, delegation, collaboration.",
"limitations": "People may regress under stress."
}
],

"Review weekly for priority drift."

{
"name": "Applying Habit 6: Synergize",

"Frame disagreements as inputs to creativity.",
"Assign roles based on strengths.",
"Create psychological safety.",

"examples_for_startups": [

{

]

{
"title": "The Daily Stoic",
"author": "Ryan Holiday",

"Obstacles are opportunities for growth.",
"Memento Mori: awareness of mortality sharpens focus.",
"Amor Fati: loving reality instead of resisting it.",

]
},

"What you don’t control: external events, outcomes, others’ behavior.",

"Justice → fairness, integrity, service to others.",
"Temperance → self-control, moderation."

"when_it_applies": "Decisions, leadership, ethics, relationships.",

},
{

"components": [
"Identify worst-case challenges.",
"Visualize calm response.",
"Prepare systems or buffers.",
"Accept what cannot be prevented."

"when_it_applies": "Planning, risk management, high-pressure environments.",

},
{

{

"Live with gratitude and depth."

"limitations": "Can be misread as nihilism when misunderstood."
},
{
"name": "Amor Fati",

"Positive interpretation of challenges.",
"Harmony with events outside your control."
],
"when_it_applies": "Stressful events, unexpected outcomes.",

}
],
