{
"title": "Thinking, Fast and Slow",
"author": "Daniel Kahneman",
"category": "Decision-Making / Cognitive Psychology / Behavioral Economics",
"tags": ["biases", "cognitive psychology", "heuristics", "decision-making", "system 1", "system 2"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "Humans rely heavily on fast, intuitive thinking (System 1), which uses heuristics and mental shortcuts. This leads to predictable cognitive biases. Slow, deliberate thinking (System 2) can override these biases — but only with effort and awareness.",
"problem_statement": "Leaders and founders unknowingly rely on flawed intuition, misjudge probabilities, fall for biases, and make systematic errors that affect decisions.",
"target_audience": "Founders, analysts, investors, product builders, leaders, negotiators.",
"promised_transformation": "A deep understanding of biases, how humans think, and how to make more rational decisions by activating System 2 deliberately.",
"key_ideas": [
"System 1 = fast, automatic, emotional, intuitive.",
"System 2 = slow, effortful, logical.",
"Biases arise from System 1 shortcuts applied in complex situations.",
"Loss aversion heavily influences human decisions.",
"People are bad at statistics, probabilities, and forecasting.",
"Overconfidence is pervasive — we think we know more than we do.",
"Narrative fallacy makes us invent stories to explain randomness.",
"Anchoring, framing, availability, representativeness distort judgment."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "System 1 and System 2 Thinking",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Two mental systems governing human reasoning.",
"components": [
"System 1 → fast, automatic, emotional, pattern-based.",
"System 2 → slow, deliberate, effortful, rational.",
"System 1 runs the show; System 2 ‘approves’ or corrects."
],
"when_it_applies": "Pitching, hiring, analysis, negotiations.",
"limitations": "System 2 is lazy; biases persist even with training."
},
{
"name": "Cognitive Biases",
"type": "model",
"description": "Systematic errors in thinking caused by heuristic shortcuts.",
"components": [
"Anchoring Bias",
"Availability Heuristic",
"Representativeness Heuristic",
"Loss Aversion",
"Confirmation Bias",
"Overconfidence Effect",
"Hindsight Bias",
"Framing Effect",
"Base Rate Neglect",
"Regression to the Mean"
],
"when_it_applies": "Strategic decisions, investing, hiring, product research.",
"limitations": "Becoming aware of biases doesn’t eliminate them."
},
{
"name": "Prospect Theory",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Explains how humans evaluate risk and value in non-rational ways.",
"components": [
"Losses hurt more than gains feel good (loss aversion).",
"People overweight low probabilities.",
"People underweight high probabilities.",
"Reference points matter more than absolute results."
],
"when_it_applies": "Pricing, negotiation, user behavior, GTM strategy.",
"limitations": "Not a full rational model — describes behavior but not ideal action."
},
{
"name": "The Planning Fallacy",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Humans underestimate time, cost, and complexity — even when they know better.",
"components": [
"Optimism bias.",
"Ignoring historical evidence.",
"Underestimating delays and constraints."
],
"when_it_applies": "Project timelines, product roadmap, hiring capacity.",
"limitations": "Awareness reduces but doesn’t eliminate overconfidence."
},
{
"name": "The Narrative Fallacy",
"type": "model",
"description": "Humans create stories to explain random events — making patterns where none exist.",
"components": [
"We prefer stories over data.",
"We assign intention to randomness.",
"We simplify complex systems with flawed narratives."
],
"when_it_applies": "Startup retros, founder storytelling, investor analysis.",
"limitations": "Hard to override emotional need for coherence."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Bias-Aware Decision-Making for Founders",
"related_framework": "Cognitive Biases + System 1/System 2",
"use_case": "Founders want to improve the quality of strategic decisions.",
"steps": [
"List key decisions requiring slow thinking.",
"Introduce a mandatory ‘System 2 pause’: 24-hour cooling period.",
"Actively check for biases (loss aversion, anchoring, optimism).",
"Use base rates: ask ‘What usually happens?’",
"Run red team/blue team analyses.",
"Document assumptions explicitly."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Avoiding overhiring based on overconfidence.",
"Preventing overpayment in acquisitions (anchoring)."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Believing intelligence protects against bias.",
"Rushing big decisions.",
"Ignoring emotional states."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Decision quality score.",
"Accuracy of forecasts vs reality.",
"Frequency of bias-flagged decisions."
]
},
{
"name": "Prospect Theory in GTM and Pricing",
"related_framework": "Prospect Theory",
"use_case": "Startup wants to design user behavior, retention, and pricing aligned with human psychology.",
"steps": [
"Design pricing to minimize perceived loss.",
"Frame offers around avoiding negative outcomes.",
"Use decoys to shape reference points.",
"Highlight gains relative to the default status quo.",
"A/B test frames: ‘Lose out on X’ vs ‘Gain X’."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"‘Don’t lose your progress’ messaging in SaaS.",
"Limited trial expiry framing (‘Keep your data’)."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Manipulative framing.",
"Overusing loss aversion → user fatigue."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Conversion rates by frame.",
"User churn after loss-framed nudges.",
"Perceived value in surveys."
]
}
]
}

{
"title": "The Great Mental Models",
"author": "Shane Parrish (Farnam Street)",
"category": "Decision-Making / Thinking / Multi-disciplinary Reasoning",
"tags": ["mental models", "decision-making", "thinking frameworks", "clarity", "reasoning", "first principles"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "You think better when you think using multiple mental models — tools drawn from physics, mathematics, biology, economics, psychology, and philosophy. The more models you have, the better your ability to understand reality.",
"problem_statement": "Most people rely on a single mental model or one discipline, leading to blindspots, poor decisions, and predictable thinking errors.",
"target_audience": "Founders, leaders, analysts, investors, product thinkers, strategists, lifelong learners.",
"promised_transformation": "A cross-disciplinary toolkit for clearer thinking, better decision-making, solving complex problems, and avoiding traps that come from narrow, linear thinking.",
"key_ideas": [
"Mental models act as cognitive tools for understanding and navigating reality.",
"The world is multi-disciplinary; good decisions require models from many domains.",
"First Principles help you break down problems.",
"Inversion (thinking backward) helps reveal failure modes.",
"Second-order thinking avoids unintended consequences.",
"Probabilistic thinking reduces overconfidence and improves forecasts.",
"Systems thinking helps you see interactions, feedback loops, and hidden dynamics.",
"Circle of Competence prevents overreach.",
"Redundancy and margin of safety protect you from uncertainty."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "First Principles Thinking",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Break complex problems into fundamental truths, then reassemble them from the ground up.",
"components": [
"Identify assumptions.",
"Break down to basic truths.",
"Reason upward from fundamentals.",
"Rebuild solution from scratch."
],
"when_it_applies": "Product strategy, innovation, pricing, technical decisions.",
"limitations": "Time-consuming; requires deep domain understanding."
},
{
"name": "Inversion",
"type": "framework",
"description": "To solve a problem, think about the opposite — how to prevent success — then avoid those failure paths.",
"components": [
"Define desired outcome.",
"Invert the problem: how to achieve the opposite?",
"Identify failure patterns.",
"Avoid or remove them systematically."
],
"when_it_applies": "Risk management, planning, product development.",
"limitations": "Must combine with forward thinking."
},
{
"name": "Second-Order Thinking",
"type": "model",
"description": "Considers consequences of consequences — not just the first effect.",
"components": [
"Immediate effect.",
"Secondary and tertiary effects.",
"Time delay between effects.",
"Unintended consequences."
],
"when_it_applies": "Policy design, org design, growth loops.",
"limitations": "Hard to quantify long-term consequences."
},
{
"name": "Probabilistic Thinking",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Making decisions based on likelihood, uncertainty, and expected value.",
"components": [
"Assign probabilities.",
"Use base rates.",
"Calculate expected value.",
"Update beliefs with new information."
],
"when_it_applies": "Hiring, investing, forecasting, experiments.",
"limitations": "People dislike probabilistic uncertainty."
},
{
"name": "Circle of Competence",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Operate within areas where you truly understand reality; avoid acting where you lack expertise.",
"components": [
"Identify what you know well.",
"Identify what you don’t know.",
"Only take big bets inside your circle.",
"Expand circle slowly through learning."
],
"when_it_applies": "Hiring, product choices, investments.",
"limitations": "Easy to misjudge competence."
},
{
"name": "Margin of Safety",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Build buffers to protect against uncertainty and volatility.",
"components": [
"Redundancy.",
"Slack.",
"Cash reserves.",
"Contingency plans."
],
"when_it_applies": "Finance, operations, engineering, hiring.",
"limitations": "Too much slack reduces efficiency."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Using First Principles for Product Strategy",
"related_framework": "First Principles Thinking",
"use_case": "Founder wants to simplify complex product decisions.",
"steps": [
"Write down the problem.",
"List all assumptions.",
"Strip assumptions to fundamental truths.",
"Rebuild a solution from the ground up.",
"Test rebuilt model with real data."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Founders reduce pricing model to pure value + willingness-to-pay data.",
"Rebuilding GTM from scratch instead of copying competitors."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Stopping at assumptions.",
"Intellectualizing without execution."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Clarity of reasoning.",
"Speed of decision-making.",
"Effectiveness of rebuilt solutions."
]
},
{
"name": "Designing Systems with Second-Order Thinking",
"related_framework": "Second-Order Thinking",
"use_case": "Startup wants to avoid unintended consequences in scaling.",
"steps": [
"Map first-order effects.",
"List second-order effects.",
"List long-tail consequences.",
"Simulate outcomes.",
"Optimize system for long-term stability."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Aggressive discounts → high churn customers.",
"Hiring fast → diluted culture → long-term decline."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Over-focusing on short-term gains.",
"Ignoring subtle delayed consequences."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Retention trends.",
"Churn by cohort.",
"Quality of downstream effects."
]
}
]
}

{
"title": "Antifragile",
"author": "Nassim Nicholas Taleb",
"category": "Decision-Making / Risk / Systems / Philosophy",
"tags": ["antifragility", "risk", "volatility", "uncertainty", "via negativa", "skin in the game"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "Fragile things break under stress, robust things resist stress, but antifragile things get stronger when exposed to disorder and volatility. You must design yourself, your decisions, and your systems to benefit from uncertainty.",
"problem_statement": "Founders try to avoid randomness and volatility — but this often increases fragility. They over-optimize for efficiency, reduce redundancy, and rely on forecasts that can't survive reality.",
"target_audience": "Founders, operators, investors, strategists, economists, product builders.",
"promised_transformation": "A worldview that lets you design systems, careers, and companies that grow stronger in chaos — instead of being harmed by it.",
"key_ideas": [
"Antifragile systems benefit from volatility.",
"Disorder, randomness, and stressors can strengthen you.",
"Redundancy, optionality, and ‘via negativa’ increase robustness.",
"Forecasting is fragile; avoid over-reliance on predictions.",
"Skin in the Game improves judgment and ethics.",
"Optionality — having more choices — is a key source of antifragility.",
"Barbell Strategy: avoid the middle; combine extreme safety + extreme risk.",
"Nonlinear payoffs → small bets with huge upside.",
"Remove what doesn't work before adding more (‘via negativa’)."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "Fragile → Robust → Antifragile Spectrum",
"type": "framework",
"description": "A classification of responses to stress:",
"components": [
"Fragile → harmed by volatility.",
"Robust → resists volatility.",
"Antifragile → benefits from volatility."
],
"when_it_applies": "Product, finance, operations, personal development.",
"limitations": "Requires discomfort and exposure to randomness."
},
{
"name": "The Barbell Strategy",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Avoid the fragile middle; combine extreme safety with small, high-upside bets.",
"components": [
"90% hyper-safe foundation.",
"10% high-risk asymmetric opportunities.",
"Limit downside; maximize upside."
],
"when_it_applies": "Finance, career, product experiments, innovation.",
"limitations": "Requires discipline and long time horizons."
},
{
"name": "Optionality",
"type": "model",
"description": "The value of having more choices, more flexibility, and more upside exposure.",
"components": [
"Retain adaptability.",
"Create multiple small bets.",
"Avoid binding long-term commitments.",
"Maximize upside optionality."
],
"when_it_applies": "Hiring, GTM, experimentation, investments.",
"limitations": "Too many options can create distraction."
},
{
"name": "Via Negativa",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Removing harmful things is more powerful than adding new things.",
"components": [
"Remove dependencies.",
"Remove complexity.",
"Remove fragilities.",
"Subtract, don’t add."
],
"when_it_applies": "Process design, productivity, health, architecture.",
"limitations": "Subtraction alone cannot solve all issues."
},
{
"name": "Convexity and Nonlinear Payoffs",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Systems with convex exposure benefit from volatility — losses are limited, upside is unlimited.",
"components": [
"Limited downside.",
"Unlimited or large upside.",
"Volatility becomes an asset.",
"Small experiments → huge discoveries."
],
"when_it_applies": "Product experiments, hiring, marketing, VC investing.",
"limitations": "Nonlinear opportunities are rare and require exploration."
},
{
"name": "Skin in the Game",
"type": "principle",
"description": "People must share the consequences of their decisions — good or bad.",
"components": [
"Symmetry of risk.",
"Accountability.",
"Ethics through exposure.",
"Decision quality improves when stakes are real."
],
"when_it_applies": "Leadership, compensation design, partnerships.",
"limitations": "Not all stakeholders can have equal exposure."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Designing an Antifragile Startup",
"related_framework": "Barbell Strategy + Optionality",
"use_case": "Founder wants to survive chaos and benefit from unknown unknowns.",
"steps": [
"Create safe base: cash reserves, efficient ops, redundancy.",
"Run many small experiments with asymmetric upside.",
"Prefer options over commitments (month-to-month tools, flexible hiring).",
"Kill bad ideas fast (via negativa).",
"Double down on convex winners.",
"Avoid forecasts — use scenario planning instead."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Testing 10 marketing channels with $100 each instead of $10,000 on one.",
"Hiring contractors first; full-time later.",
"Building modular systems instead of monoliths."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Over-betting on risky ideas.",
"Ignoring the safe base.",
"Treating optionality as lack of direction."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Option creation rate.",
"Failure cost vs upside potential.",
"Runway redundancy.",
"Number of convex wins per quarter."
]
},
{
"name": "Applying Via Negativa in Operations",
"related_framework": "Via Negativa",
"use_case": "Startup wants efficiency without adding complexity.",
"steps": [
"List current processes.",
"Identify fragilities (bottlenecks, dependencies).",
"Remove unnecessary steps.",
"Standardize recurring tasks.",
"Simplify workflows.",
"Reduce cognitive load."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Eliminating unnecessary meetings.",
"Removing features users don’t use.",
"Automating repetitive tasks."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Cutting essential things.",
"Removing too much and breaking systems."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Process speed.",
"Error rate.",
"Team cognitive load score.",
"Reduction in failure points."
]
}
]
}

{
"title": "Deep Work",

"category": "Mindset / Productivity / Focus",
"tags": ["deep work", "focus", "productivity", "attention", "craftsmanship", "discipline"],

],

],

]
},
{

"Create ‘shutdown routine’ to exit cleanly.",
"Record number of minutes in deep work daily."
],

"Evening strategy review ritual."
],
"failure_modes": [

"Letting emergencies derail routines.",
"No clear boundaries with team."
],
"metrics_to_track": [

"Minutes to reach flow state.",
"Quality of deep work outcomes."
]
},
{

{
"title": "The Design of Everyday Things",
"author": "Don Norman",
"category": "Product / UX / Design",
"tags": ["UX design", "usability", "human-centered design", "affordances", "error prevention", "product design"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "Good design makes products understandable and usable by aligning with how people actually think, perceive, and behave. When something is confusing, it’s usually a design problem, not a user problem.",
"problem_statement": "Products are often built around internal logic, constraints, or aesthetics rather than human cognition. This leads to confusion, misuse, and frustration that gets blamed on ‘stupid users’ instead of poor design.",
"target_audience": "Product managers, UX designers, engineers, founders, anyone designing products, interfaces, or systems people must use.",
"promised_transformation": "A human-centered design mindset and vocabulary for diagnosing usability issues, designing intuitive interfaces, and creating products that ‘explain themselves’ to users.",
"key_ideas": [
"Design should be human-centered, not system-centered.",
"Affordances and signifiers help users know what actions are possible.",
"Conceptual models shape how people understand and predict system behavior.",
"Feedback and visibility reduce confusion and errors.",
"Constraints guide users toward correct actions and away from mistakes.",
"Most ‘user errors’ are in fact design errors.",
"Iterative design with real user testing is essential for good products."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "Affordances and Signifiers",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Affordances are the possible actions an object allows; signifiers are cues that communicate those possibilities to users.",
"components": [
"Affordances → what can be done (click, drag, swipe, turn).",
"Signifiers → visual/physical cues that indicate the affordance (button shape, label, icon).",
"Perceived Affordance → what users *think* they can do, based on signifiers."
],
"when_it_applies": "Designing UI controls, physical products, onboarding flows, calls to action.",
"limitations": "Overuse of decorative visuals can weaken signifiers and confuse affordances."
},
{
"name": "Conceptual Models",
"type": "model",
"description": "The mental model users form about how a system works. Good design shapes accurate models.",
"components": [
"System image → what the interface and behavior communicate.",
"User’s mental model → how they think it works.",
"Designer’s model → how it actually works internally.",
"Goal: align user model with designer model through the system image."
],
"when_it_applies": "Feature design, navigation structure, onboarding, complex workflows.",
"limitations": "Different user groups may hold different conceptual models; can’t satisfy all perfectly."
},
{
"name": "The Seven Stages of Action",
"type": "framework",
"description": "A model describing how users form goals, act, and evaluate outcomes when interacting with systems.",
"components": [
"Forming the goal.",
"Forming the intention.",
"Specifying an action.",
"Executing the action.",
"Perceiving the state of the world.",
"Interpreting the state.",
"Evaluating the outcome relative to goal."
],
"when_it_applies": "Task design, UX flows, error analysis, onboarding.",
"limitations": "In real life, users might skip or compress stages unconsciously."
},
{
"name": "Gulfs of Execution and Evaluation",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Two key gaps in usability: how hard it is to perform actions, and how hard it is to understand results.",
"components": [
"Gulf of Execution → can I figure out how to do what I want?",
"Gulf of Evaluation → can I tell what happened and if it worked?",
"Good design shrinks both gulfs with clear controls and feedback."
],
"when_it_applies": "Every interaction: buttons, forms, multi-step flows, error recovery.",
"limitations": "Complex systems may never fully eliminate these gulfs; they can only minimize them."
},
{
"name": "Constraints in Design",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Limitations and rules that narrow user actions to reduce errors and make behavior clearer.",
"components": [
"Physical constraints (shape, size).",
"Cultural constraints (conventions, norms).",
"Logical constraints (only one thing makes sense).",
"Semantic constraints (meaning from context)."
],
"when_it_applies": "Form fields, wizards, physical controls, safety-critical actions.",
"limitations": "Overly restrictive constraints can frustrate power users."
},
{
"name": "Human-Centered Design (HCD) Cycle",
"type": "framework",
"description": "An iterative design process centered around users’ needs, contexts, and feedback.",
"components": [
"Observe and research users.",
"Generate ideas and models.",
"Prototype.",
"Test with users.",
"Iterate based on feedback."
],
"when_it_applies": "New product development, feature launches, UX revamps.",
"limitations": "Requires time and real user access; often skipped under deadline pressure."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Running a UX Audit Using Gulfs & Affordances",
"related_framework": "Gulfs of Execution and Evaluation + Affordances and Signifiers",
"use_case": "A startup wants to make its product more intuitive and reduce user confusion without a full redesign.",
"steps": [
"Pick 3–5 core user tasks (signup, first action, key workflow).",
"For each step, ask: ‘What does the user want to do here?’",
"Check if controls have clear signifiers (buttons look clickable, inputs look editable, etc.).",
"Identify gaps in the Gulf of Execution: where would a first-time user feel stuck?",
"Check feedback after actions: is it obvious what happened? Success, error, next step?",
"List all confusing or ambiguous elements and categorize them: missing signifier, unclear feedback, poor labeling, hidden constraints.",
"Prioritize fixes that shrink gulfs and strengthen signifiers for critical paths.",
"Re-test with 3–5 users and iterate."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Improving sign-in/sign-up clarity: separate buttons, clear labels like ‘New here? Create an account.’",
"Adding inline validation and success states in forms to reduce evaluation uncertainty."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Designers defending aesthetics over clarity.",
"Fixing visual details but not core flows.",
"Ignoring error states and only designing happy paths."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Task completion rate for key flows.",
"Time to complete core tasks on first use.",
"Support tickets related to ‘how do I…?’ questions.",
"User satisfaction (post-task surveys or NPS for onboarding)."
]
},
{
"name": "Designing Onboarding with Conceptual Models",
"related_framework": "Conceptual Models + Human-Centered Design Cycle",
"use_case": "A SaaS product wants new users to ‘get it’ in the first 5 minutes without hand-holding.",
"steps": [
"Ask: ‘If our product were a physical object, what would it be?’ (e.g., whiteboard, assistant, control panel).",
"Define a simple conceptual metaphor to guide UI (e.g., ‘projects’ → folders, ‘workspaces’ → rooms).",
"Align labels, navigation, and icons with that metaphor consistently.",
"Introduce a short, contextual walkthrough emphasizing the conceptual model (e.g., ‘Think of this as your control center…’).",
"Remove or hide advanced options that contradict the initial model for first-time users.",
"Test with 5 users: ask them to explain how the product works in their own words after 5 minutes.",
"Iterate until their mental model matches your intended model."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Project management tool framed as a ‘digital kanban board’ instead of abstract lists.",
"Analytics product framed as a ‘health dashboard’ for your business with gauges and dials."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Mixing metaphors (e.g., folders + boards + pipelines all at once).",
"Using internal jargon as labels.",
"Skipping user testing because ‘it’s obvious to us.’"
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Time to first key action (TTFA).",
"User explanation accuracy in interviews (‘Tell me what this does’).",
"Onboarding completion rate.",
"Feature adoption in the first 7 days."
]
},
{
"name": "Using Constraints to Reduce User Errors",
"related_framework": "Constraints in Design",
"use_case": "A startup sees frequent user mistakes in forms, workflows, or configuration steps.",
"steps": [
"Identify top 5 most common user errors (from logs, support tickets).",
"For each error, map where the user’s choice space is too wide or ambiguous.",
"Introduce physical or logical constraints: dropdown instead of free text, allowed ranges, defaults, or step-by-step wizards.",
"Use semantic constraints and copy: helper text, examples, warning labels.",
"Add clear feedback when constraints are hit: inline validation, hints, and suggestions.",
"Re-run flows with new users and observe if errors decrease.",
"Refine constraints to balance safety and flexibility."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Limiting date ranges for reports to avoid huge, slow queries.",
"Preventing destructive actions (like delete) without confirmation and clear labeling."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Over-constraining and frustrating expert users.",
"Hidden constraints that are not communicated (user thinks it’s a bug).",
"Cryptic error messages that don’t guide recovery."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Error rate per critical flow.",
"Support tickets related to misconfiguration.",
"Time to successfully complete complex tasks.",
"Drop-off at form/flow steps."
]
}
]
}

{
"title": "Escaping the Build Trap",
"author": "Melissa Perri",
"category": "Product / Strategy / Product Management",
"tags": ["product strategy", "outcome-driven", "product discovery", "build trap", "product management", "value creation"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "Companies fall into the Build Trap when they measure success by the volume of features shipped instead of outcomes delivered. True product success comes from solving real customer problems, not building more stuff.",
"problem_statement": "Organizations reward output, not outcomes. Teams chase roadmaps, velocity, and feature checklists instead of value creation, leading to bloated products, wasted effort, and no real customer impact.",
"target_audience": "Founders, PMs, product leaders, engineering managers, designers, and executives.",
"promised_transformation": "A shift to an outcome-driven product organization where teams solve problems, create customer value, and align product work with business strategy.",
"key_ideas": [
"The Build Trap = when companies over-focus on shipping features instead of solving problems.",
"PMs should act as problem-finders, not backlog managers.",
"Strategy connects company goals → product initiatives → experiments.",
"Discovery and delivery must run continuously, not sequentially.",
"A good product manager is a mini-CEO of the problem, not the solution.",
"Strong product organizations prioritize learning over output.",
"Executives must empower teams with clear goals, not tasks.",
"Roadmaps should be about outcomes, not features."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "The Build Trap",
"type": "model",
"description": "A dysfunctional cycle where teams measure success by number of features shipped rather than customer or business impact.",
"components": [
"Feature factory mindset.",
"No clear strategy.",
"PMs act like project managers.",
"Output-driven roadmaps.",
"No customer understanding.",
"Poor alignment between leadership and product teams."
],
"when_it_applies": "Organizations releasing many features but not improving metrics.",
"limitations": "Requires leadership change to escape."
},
{
"name": "Product Kata",
"type": "framework",
"description": "An iterative learning loop for product teams inspired by Toyota Kata.",
"components": [
"Set an outcome goal.",
"Understand the current state.",
"Form hypotheses.",
"Run experiments.",
"Measure learning and adjust."
],
"when_it_applies": "Problem discovery, experimentation, new features.",
"limitations": "Needs disciplined measurement culture."
},
{
"name": "Product vs Project Mindset",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Product = continuous problem solving and value creation; Project = delivering a predefined scope.",
"components": [
"Product: ongoing, iterative, customer-centered.",
"Project: deadline-driven, scope-fixed, output-oriented.",
"Great PMs own the problem, not the feature."
],
"when_it_applies": "Strategic planning, roadmap creation, hiring PMs.",
"limitations": "Organizations often default to project mindset under pressure."
},
{
"name": "Product Operating Model",
"type": "framework",
"description": "How product organizations structure teams, processes, and decision-making.",
"components": [
"Empowered teams.",
"Clear strategic goals.",
"Outcome-based roadmaps.",
"Continuous learning.",
"Cross-functional collaboration."
],
"when_it_applies": "Scaling product teams, reorganizing roles, aligning executives.",
"limitations": "Requires culture change; cannot be applied superficially."
},
{
"name": "Strategy Pyramid",
"type": "framework",
"description": "A hierarchy aligning company goals → product initiatives → experiments.",
"components": [
"Company vision.",
"Business objectives.",
"Product initiatives.",
"Outcome metrics.",
"Tactical experiments."
],
"when_it_applies": "Annual planning, OKRs, product strategy creation.",
"limitations": "Falls apart if executives give outputs instead of goals."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Transforming a Feature Factory into a Product Organization",
"related_framework": "Product Operating Model + Strategy Pyramid",
"use_case": "Startup ships many features but metrics are flat.",
"steps": [
"Write outcome-based goals for each team.",
"Replace feature roadmaps with problem roadmaps.",
"Train PMs to form hypotheses, not task checklists.",
"Introduce weekly product review focused on learning.",
"Run discovery activities (interviews, data analysis).",
"Introduce Product Kata loops.",
"Align executives around strategy and expected outcomes."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Shift from ‘Build new dashboard’ → ‘Increase activation by 20%’.",
"From ‘Add 5 filters’ → ‘Reduce search time by 30%’."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Executives still dictating outputs.",
"PMs acting like backlog owners.",
"Engineering pressured to deliver velocity instead of value."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Outcome metric movement.",
"Hypotheses tested per month.",
"Customer problem clarity score.",
"Strategy alignment score."
]
},
{
"name": "Running Product Kata Weekly",
"related_framework": "Product Kata",
"use_case": "Founder wants continuous product learning.",
"steps": [
"Define target outcome.",
"Analyze current baseline.",
"Identify constraints & opportunities.",
"Form hypotheses.",
"Design experiments.",
"Run, measure, learn.",
"Repeat."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Activation funnel experiments.",
"Pricing experiments.",
"Improving onboarding completion."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Jumping to solutions without evidence.",
"Running experiments without metrics.",
"Not revisiting initial assumptions."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Experiment cadence.",
"Ratio of validated vs invalidated hypotheses.",
"Time-to-learning."
]
}
]
}

{
"title": "Continuous Discovery Habits",
"author": "Teresa Torres",
"category": "Product / Discovery / User Research",
"tags": ["product discovery", "continuous discovery", "customer interviews", "assumption mapping", "opportunity solution tree", "experimentation"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "Sustainable product success comes from continuous discovery — weekly touchpoints with customers, rapid assumption testing, and a structured way to explore opportunities before building solutions.",
"problem_statement": "Most teams treat discovery as a one-time phase, rely on opinions, or validate ideas after they’ve already invested in them.",
"target_audience": "PMs, founders, designers, engineers, product trios, research teams.",
"promised_transformation": "A repeatable, lightweight, week-to-week discovery system that keeps teams close to customers, tests assumptions early, and avoids building the wrong things.",
"key_ideas": [
"Discovery is continuous, not a phase.",
"Product decisions must be informed by weekly customer conversations.",
"Opportunity Solution Trees (OST) clarify problem spaces.",
"Assumption testing reduces risk before building.",
"The Product Trio (PM + Designer + Engineer) drives decisions together.",
"Interviews should focus on past behavior, not opinions.",
"Rapid prototyping accelerates learning.",
"Teams must narrow to one opportunity at a time."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "Opportunity Solution Tree (OST)",
"type": "framework",
"description": "A visual model that organizes product decisions: outcomes → opportunities → solutions → experiments.",
"components": [
"Outcome (business result).",
"Opportunities (customer problems/needs).",
"Solutions (behavior-changing ideas).",
"Experiments (tests validating assumptions)."
],
"when_it_applies": "Strategic exploration, prioritization, early discovery.",
"limitations": "Can become complex if too many opportunities are tracked."
},
{
"name": "The Product Trio",
"type": "model",
"description": "Decision-making unit: PM + Designer + Engineer work together throughout discovery & delivery.",
"components": [
"Shared understanding.",
"Joint research.",
"Joint experimentation.",
"Cross-functional alignment."
],
"when_it_applies": "All discovery activities and early ideation.",
"limitations": "Requires commitment from engineering org."
},
{
"name": "Continuous Interviewing",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Weekly customer conversations that uncover opportunities based on past behavior.",
"components": [
"Identify target customer segments.",
"Schedule 1-2 interviews weekly.",
"Focus on stories, not opinions.",
"Extract opportunities from behaviors."
],
"when_it_applies": "Every stage of product development.",
"limitations": "Unstructured conversations produce noisy insight."
},
{
"name": "Assumption Mapping",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Identify and prioritize risky assumptions before prototyping.",
"components": [
"Feasibility assumptions.",
"Usability assumptions.",
"Value assumptions.",
"Viability assumptions.",
"Prioritize by risk and uncertainty."
],
"when_it_applies": "Pre-prototyping, early idea evaluation.",
"limitations": "Teams often underestimate value and viability risks."
},
{
"name": "Rapid Customer-Focused Experimentation",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Learning through lightweight tests before investing heavily.",
"components": [
"Fake door tests.",
"Landing pages.",
"Clickable prototypes.",
"Wizard-of-Oz flows.",
"Time-boxed experiments."
],
"when_it_applies": "Risky bets, innovation, new features.",
"limitations": "False positives possible if experiments are too low fidelity."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Implementing Continuous Discovery as a Weekly Habit",
"related_framework": "Continuous Interviewing + OST",
"use_case": "Founders want continuous alignment with customer needs.",
"steps": [
"Form a Product Trio (PM, Designer, Engineer).",
"Schedule weekly customer interviews.",
"Create initial Opportunity Solution Tree.",
"Extract opportunities from each interview.",
"Prioritize most promising opportunity.",
"Identify riskiest assumptions.",
"Design experiments for those assumptions.",
"Learn, update the OST, and repeat weekly."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Early-stage SaaS validating ICP needs weekly.",
"Marketplace platform understanding buyer-seller friction."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Interviewing only when convenient.",
"Jumping to solutions immediately.",
"Not mapping assumptions."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Weekly interviews completed.",
"Opportunity clarity score.",
"Validated assumptions per month.",
"Experiment-to-learning cycle time."
]
},
{
"name": "Building Your First Opportunity Solution Tree",
"related_framework": "Opportunity Solution Tree",
"use_case": "Team wants clarity on which opportunities to pursue.",
"steps": [
"Define target outcome (OKR).",
"List opportunities from existing customer insights.",
"Cluster opportunities into themes.",
"Use interviews to validate which are real and important.",
"Choose one opportunity to focus on.",
"Generate multiple solution ideas.",
"Map risky assumptions for each solution.",
"Design experiments.",
"Execute, learn, and refine the OST."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Activation improvement OST.",
"Retention-focused OST for B2B SaaS.",
"Pricing strategy OST."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Treating OST as a to-do list.",
"Having too many opportunities active.",
"Solving for low-impact opportunities."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Number of opportunities validated.",
"Outcome movement (activation, retention, revenue).",
"Time from idea → experiment → learning."
]
},
{
"name": "Running Assumption Mapping Before Building Anything",
"related_framework": "Assumption Mapping",
"use_case": "Avoid wasting engineering time.",
"steps": [
"Identify all assumptions for each solution idea.",
"Classify into usability, value, feasibility, viability.",
"Prioritize based on risk + uncertainty.",
"Design tests for the riskiest assumptions first.",
"Use rapid, low-fidelity experiments.",
"Kill or pivot ideas with invalidated assumptions."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Testing willingness to pay via pricing landing page.",
"Validating usability with clickable prototypes."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Ignoring viability assumptions (legal, revenue, compliance).",
"Jumping straight to building MVP.",
"Poor experiment design."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Assumptions invalidated early.",
"Engineering hours saved.",
"Experiment cycle time.",
"Viability alignment score."
]
}
]
}

{
"title": "Lean UX",
"author": "Jeff Gothelf",
"category": "Product / UX / Lean / Agile",
"tags": ["lean ux", "agile", "product teams", "collaboration", "experimentation", "MVP", "hypothesis-driven"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "Lean UX replaces heavy documentation with continuous collaboration, rapid experimentation, and shared understanding to create products that deliver real value. It brings Lean Startup principles into the design process.",
"problem_statement": "Traditional UX processes rely on extensive upfront design and handoffs, leading to slow learning, wasted effort, and products built on assumptions rather than validated insights.",
"target_audience": "Product teams, UX designers, PMs, engineers, startups, agile teams.",
"promised_transformation": "A faster, collaborative, experiment-driven approach to UX where teams learn continuously, ship faster, and deliver validated product value.",
"key_ideas": [
"Lean UX prioritizes learning over deliverables.",
"Cross-functional teams work collaboratively, not in silos.",
"Shared understanding reduces documentation needs.",
"Hypotheses replace requirements.",
"Experiments test assumptions quickly and cheaply.",
"Outcomes matter more than features.",
"Continuous discovery and iterative design improve customer value."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "Lean UX Process",
"type": "framework",
"description": "A cycle of discovery → framing → ideation → experimentation → learning → iteration.",
"components": [
"Declare assumptions.",
"Form hypotheses.",
"Design small experiments.",
"Collect data from users.",
"Learn, refine, or pivot."
],
"when_it_applies": "Uncertainty, new features, MVPs, redesigns, agile environments.",
"limitations": "Requires cultural shift away from documentation-heavy processes."
},
{
"name": "Hypothesis Statements",
"type": "framework",
"description": "A structured format for turning assumptions into testable hypotheses.",
"components": [
"We believe that...",
"For this user...",
"This outcome will happen...",
"We will know we are right when..."
],
"when_it_applies": "Feature ideas, UX flows, experiments, product strategy.",
"limitations": "Poorly worded hypotheses lead to weak experiments."
},
{
"name": "Collaborative Design",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Design is created together by PMs, designers, and engineers in real time.",
"components": [
"Workshopping solutions.",
"Sketching together.",
"Shared whiteboards.",
"Team decision-making."
],
"when_it_applies": "Early-stage ideation, concept mapping, reducing handoffs.",
"limitations": "Needs facilitation; can get messy without structure."
},
{
"name": "MVP Experiments",
"type": "model",
"description": "Testing ideas with the smallest experiment that yields useful learning.",
"components": [
"Prototypes.",
"Landing pages.",
"Concierge tests.",
"Wizard-of-Oz flows.",
"A/B tests."
],
"when_it_applies": "Validating demand, usability, value, feasibility.",
"limitations": "Low-fidelity MVPs may sometimes misrepresent the product."
},
{
"name": "Outcomes Over Outputs",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Success is measured by changes in user behavior, not by shipping features.",
"components": [
"Outcome metrics.",
"User behaviors.",
"Value delivered.",
"Impact on business goals."
],
"when_it_applies": "OKRs, roadmapping, strategy.",
"limitations": "Requires org buy-in and leadership alignment."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Running a Lean UX Cycle",
"related_framework": "Lean UX Process",
"use_case": "Startup wants to validate ideas without heavy design cycles.",
"steps": [
"Hold assumption-mapping workshop.",
"Identify riskiest assumptions.",
"Convert assumptions → hypothesis statements.",
"Design fast MVP experiments.",
"Test with users or real data.",
"Collect insights and refine hypotheses.",
"Repeat weekly."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Testing onboarding screens using Figma prototypes.",
"Creating a fake door for new features."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Jumping into design before clarifying hypotheses.",
"Testing too many things at once.",
"Treating experiments as validation instead of learning."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Validated assumptions per sprint.",
"Experiment cycle time.",
"Outcome movement (activation, retention)."
]
},
{
"name": "Hypothesis-Driven Roadmapping",
"related_framework": "Hypothesis Statements",
"use_case": "Founder wants product direction without committing to feature lists.",
"steps": [
"Write outcome-focused goals.",
"List major assumptions behind each goal.",
"Write hypothesis statements.",
"Prioritize by risk and uncertainty.",
"Plan experiments to validate assumptions.",
"Convert validated hypotheses into roadmap initiatives."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Roadmap item: Improve onboarding → Hypothesis: Users need a 2-step intro wizard.",
"Roadmap shift: Prioritizing pricing experiments over new features."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Treating hypotheses as requirements.",
"No owners for experiments.",
"Overly large experiments."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Hypothesis validation rate.",
"Roadmap accuracy.",
"Impact of validated vs invalidated bets."
]
}
]
}

{
"title": "Don't Make Me Think",
"author": "Steve Krug",
"category": "Product / UX / Usability",
"tags": ["usability", "web design", "user experience", "intuitive design", "heuristics", "navigation"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "Users should be able to understand and use your product without thinking. Simplicity, clarity, and intuitive design are the foundation of effective digital experiences.",
"problem_statement": "Most websites and apps make users think too much — unclear navigation, confusing copy, cluttered interfaces, hidden actions — causing frustration, drop-off, and abandonment.",
"target_audience": "Founders, PMs, designers, engineers, marketers, anyone designing digital experiences.",
"promised_transformation": "A practical set of heuristics and mental models to design ultra-simple, user-friendly digital interfaces that users can use effortlessly.",
"key_ideas": [
"Usability = don’t make people think.",
"Users scan, they don’t read.",
"Clarity beats cleverness every time.",
"Navigation must be obvious and predictable.",
"Remove question marks: don’t confuse the user.",
"Conventions are powerful — don’t reinvent basic UI patterns.",
"Testing with even 3–5 users catches major issues.",
"Every page needs a clear hierarchy.",
"Omit needless words."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "Krug’s First Law of Usability",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Don't make users think — everything should be obvious or self-explanatory.",
"components": [
"Clear signifiers.",
"Predictable patterns.",
"Minimal cognitive load."
],
"when_it_applies": "All UX design, onboarding, navigation design, landing pages.",
"limitations": "Some advanced tools may need layered complexity."
},
{

"F-pattern scanning.",
"Visual anchors.",
"Chunked information.",
"Highlighting and bolding."
],
"when_it_applies": "Web pages, dashboards, mobile UI.",
"limitations": "Complex tasks may require deeper reading."
},
{
"name": "Visual Hierarchy",

"Proximity.",
"Whitespace."

"limitations": "Poor execution causes visual noise."
},
{

"Standard layouts.",
"Familiar navigation structures.",
"Predictable interactions."
],
"when_it_applies": "Building common web/app UI.",
"limitations": "Innovation is still needed in unique workflows."
},
{
"name": "Usability Testing (Hallway Testing)",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Test with 3–5 users to uncover 80% of usability issues.",
"components": [
"Short sessions (20–30 min).",
"Simple tasks.",
"Think-aloud protocol.",
"Observe, don’t guide.",
"Fix biggest issues first."
],
"when_it_applies": "Before launches, early prototypes, redesigns.",
"limitations": "Small sample ≠ statistical significance; gives qualitative insight."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [

"Error rate in forms."

},
{

"Ask them to think aloud.",
"Observe confusion points.",
"Record recurring patterns.",
"Fix top 3 problems immediately.",
"Re-test next week."

"Testing navigation on a mobile app."

"Re-test improvements."
]
},
{

{
"title": "Shape Up",
"author": "Ryan Singer (Basecamp)",
"category": "Product / Execution / Software Process",
"tags": ["shape up", "product development", "bets", "scoping", "cycles", "basecamp", "shipping"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "Shape Up is a product development methodology that replaces agile sprints and endless backlogs with a system of shaping, betting, and executing work in 6-week cycles. It reduces chaos by defining the problem clearly and constraining teams with fixed-time projects.",
"problem_statement": "Traditional agile leads to endless backlog grooming, unclear scopes, disrupted schedules, and teams that ship late because projects grow without boundaries.",
"target_audience": "Founders, PMs, engineers, product designers, tech leads, small to mid-size product teams.",
"promised_transformation": "A clear, flexible, and realistic system to define work, reduce scope creep, empower teams, and reliably ship meaningful features within fixed time frames.",
"key_ideas": [
"Work is shaped upfront — not estimated.",
"Teams work in fixed 6-week cycles.",
"The appetite determines the scope, not the other way around.",
"Small, trusted teams execute autonomously.",
"There are no backlogs; only pitches that get bet on.",
"Risk is addressed early by solving unknowns during shaping.",
"Betting Table aligns leaders on what to work on.",
"Cool-down periods allow cleanup and exploration.",
"Scope is cut, not time."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "Shaping",
"type": "framework",
"description": "The upstream process where senior product thinkers define the problem, explore rabbit holes, and design the boundaries of a solution before handing it to a team.",
"components": [
"Raw idea → shaped pitch.",
"Define the problem clearly.",
"Set appetite (how much time is worth).",
"Design key elements and constraints.",
"Address rabbit holes upfront.",
"Remove unnecessary complexity."
],
"when_it_applies": "Before any project starts; high-stakes or ambiguous ideas.",
"limitations": "Requires senior people who understand product deeply."
},
{
"name": "Appetite",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Instead of estimating how long something will take, decide how much time you're *willing to invest* (e.g., 2 weeks or 6 weeks).",
"components": [
"Defines upper time limit.",
"Constrains scope.",
"Encourages simple solutions.",
"Avoids estimation paralysis."
],
"when_it_applies": "Prioritization, scoping, roadmap planning.",
"limitations": "Needs discipline to maintain time constraints."
},
{
"name": "Pitches",
"type": "model",
"description": "Shaped work is turned into written pitches for leaders to review and bet on.",
"components": [
"Problem statement.",
"Appetite.",
"Proposed solution.",
"No-gos & boundaries.",
"Rabbit holes addressed.",
"Risks identified."
],
"when_it_applies": "Before betting cycles.",
"limitations": "Poor pitches lead to unclear projects."
},
{
"name": "Betting Table",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Leadership reviews pitches and commits to what gets built in the next 6-week cycle.",
"components": [
"No backlog.",
"Limited number of bets.",
"All decisions reset after cycle.",
"Clear owner for each bet."
],
"when_it_applies": "Cycle planning.",
"limitations": "Needs strong prioritization discipline."
},
{
"name": "6-Week Cycles + Cool-Downs",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Teams build bets within a 6-week fixed cycle, followed by 2-week cool-down.",
"components": [
"6 weeks focused execution.",
"2 weeks cleanup + exploration.",
"No mid-cycle changes.",
"Autonomous team execution."
],
"when_it_applies": "Core product work; major features.",
"limitations": "Too rigid for emergencies."
},
{
"name": "Hill Charts",
"type": "model",
"description": "Visual progress model showing uncertainty → certainty instead of percent completion.",
"components": [
"Uphill: figuring out unknowns.",
"Peak: clarity achieved.",
"Downhill: executing known tasks."
],
"when_it_applies": "Weekly team reporting.",
"limitations": "Not a granular task management system."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Running a Full Shape Up Cycle",
"related_framework": "Shaping + Betting Table + 6-Week Cycles",
"use_case": "Startup wants predictable shipping and less chaos.",
"steps": [
"Identify raw ideas.",
"Shape 3–5 ideas into pitches.",
"Hold a Betting Table meeting.",
"Select cycle bets based on appetite.",
"Assign a small autonomous team.",
"Track via Hill Charts weekly.",
"Cut scope ruthlessly.",
"Ship at end of 6th week.",
"Use cool-down for fixes & exploration."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Shaping a new onboarding flow.",
"Building a billing system in 6 weeks.",
"Reworking notification architecture."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Shaping too lightly.",
"Mid-cycle changes from leadership.",
"Teams not empowered."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Cycle completion rate.",
"Scope cuts vs shipping.",
"Team autonomy score.",
"Time from pitch → shipped feature."
]
},
{
"name": "Creating an Effective Pitch",
"related_framework": "Pitches",
"use_case": "Founder wants clear proposals instead of vague feature requests.",
"steps": [
"Write clear problem statement.",
"Define appetite.",
"Sketch solution at the right level (fat marker level).",
"List no-gos.",
"Call out rabbit holes.",
"Estimate risk areas."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"2-week appetite for pricing page redesign.",
"6-week appetite for AI workspace revamp."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Too abstract or too detailed.",
"Not addressing uncertainties.",
"Skipping appetite."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Clarity of pitches.",
"Acceptance rate at Betting Table.",
"Execution success vs pitch assumptions."
]
}
]
}

{

"Constraints fuel creativity.",
"Your product is your team (talent is everything).",

"Create fast feedback loops with users.",

],

{
"title": "The Cathedral and the Bazaar",
"author": "Eric S. Raymond",
"category": "Tech / Open Source / Software Engineering",
"tags": ["open source", "software engineering", "community development", "bazaar model", "linux", "distributed collaboration", "release early release often"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "There are two main models of software development — the Cathedral (closed, hierarchical, tightly controlled) and the Bazaar (open, decentralized, community-driven). The Bazaar model, seen in open-source projects like Linux, can outperform traditional approaches by leveraging distributed contributions and rapid iteration.",
"problem_statement": "Traditional “Cathedral” development assumes that centralized planning and expert control produce better software — but in reality, this slows progress, hides bugs, and blocks innovation.",
"target_audience": "Engineers, CTOs, founders, open source contributors, software architects.",
"promised_transformation": "A deep understanding of how open-source communities collaborate successfully, and actionable principles for building software via distributed, transparent, iterative processes.",
"key_ideas": [
"Cathedral = controlled, slow, hierarchical. Bazaar = open, fast, emergent.",
"Open-source benefits from ‘many eyes’ — more contributors → fewer bugs.",
"Release early, release often accelerates learning and bug fixing.",
"Given enough eyeballs, all bugs are shallow (Linus’s Law).",
"Developers should treat users as co-developers.",
"Good ideas can come from anywhere, not just core maintainers.",
"Decentralized collaboration can beat top-down planning.",
"Leadership in bazaars is about coordination, not command.",
"A thriving community often matters more than technical perfection."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "The Cathedral Model",
"type": "model",
"description": "A centralized, hierarchical development model.",
"components": [
"Small, expert team.",
"Infrequent major releases.",
"Closed source until release.",
"Heavy planning and documentation.",
"Clear top-down authority."
],
"when_it_applies": "Security-critical systems, enterprise software, hardware-integrated systems.",
"limitations": "Slow iteration; high communication overhead; bottlenecks at the top."
},
{
"name": "The Bazaar Model",
"type": "framework",
"description": "A decentralized, open, collaborative model with many contributors.",
"components": [
"Open source.",
"Rapid, frequent releases.",
"Users act as co-developers.",
"Emergent design.",
"Distributed debugging and contributions."
],
"when_it_applies": "OSS projects, developer tools, community-driven platforms.",
"limitations": "Requires strong maintainers; risk of chaos without governance."
},
{
"name": "Linus’s Law",
"type": "principle",
"description": "‘Given enough eyeballs, all bugs are shallow.’",
"components": [
"Large contributor base.",
"Diverse perspectives.",
"Parallel debugging.",
"Fast discovery of edge cases."
],
"when_it_applies": "Open-source debugging, collaborative platforms.",
"limitations": "Only works with active and skilled contributors."
},
{
"name": "Release Early, Release Often",
"type": "model",
"description": "Frequent releases accelerate feedback, stabilize development, and improve quality.",
"components": [
"Short cycles.",
"Continuous improvement.",
"Real-world feedback.",
"Faster bug discovery."
],
"when_it_applies": "All modern software (especially agile/open source).",
"limitations": "Requires CI/CD and fast feedback loops."
},
{
"name": "Egoless Programming",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Treat code as shared property; focus on quality, not ownership.",
"components": [
"Open critique.",
"Peer review.",
"Collective ownership.",
"Community-driven quality."
],
"when_it_applies": "OSS teams, refactoring, scaling engineering culture.",
"limitations": "Requires humility and strong communication norms."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Adopting Bazaar Principles in a Startup",
"related_framework": "Bazaar Model + Linus’s Law",
"use_case": "Early-stage tech startup wants faster iteration and stronger engineering culture.",
"steps": [
"Open internal repos for all engineers.",
"Adopt frequent release cycles (daily/weekly).",
"Encourage cross-team code reviews.",
"Invite power users to beta test frequently.",
"Make maintainers responsible for governance, not gatekeeping.",
"Document contribution guidelines."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Building a plugin marketplace with community contributions.",
"Crowdsourcing bug reports from early evangelists."
],
"failure_modes": [
"No governance → chaos.",
"Too many opinions → decision paralysis.",
"Poor documentation → contributor frustration."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Release frequency.",
"Time-to-bug-fix.",
"Contributor growth.",
"Community engagement."
]
},
{
"name": "Using ‘Release Early, Release Often’",
"related_framework": "Release Early, Release Often",
"use_case": "Team struggles with slow shipping and high uncertainty.",
"steps": [
"Switch to small, incremental releases.",
"Automate deployment with CI/CD.",
"Introduce beta/alpha channels.",
"Collect user feedback continuously.",
"Iterate weekly based on usage and bug reports."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Launching v0.1 with just the core workflow.",
"Weekly UX improvements based on session recordings."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Releasing broken builds too often.",
"Ignoring user feedback.",
"Using frequent releases to justify lack of planning."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Release cadence.",
"Crash-free sessions.",
"Bug report volume.",
"Time between user feedback → fix."
]
}
]
}

{
"title": "Refactoring",
"author": "Martin Fowler",
"category": "Software Engineering / Code Quality",
"tags": ["refactoring", "code quality", "clean code", "design patterns", "technical debt", "software craftsmanship"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "Refactoring improves existing code by making its structure cleaner, more understandable, and easier to modify — without changing external behavior. Good design emerges from continuous, safe, incremental improvements.",
"problem_statement": "Most software degrades over time: technical debt accumulates, features become harder to add, and code becomes brittle. Teams delay refactoring until too late, causing maintenance nightmares.",
"target_audience": "Engineers, tech leads, architects, CTOs, product teams scaling engineering.",
"promised_transformation": "A systematic approach to identify code smells, apply proven refactorings, and maintain codebases that are easy to extend and safe to modify.",
"key_ideas": [
"Refactoring = changing structure without changing behavior.",
"Bad code slows everything: features, debugging, onboarding.",
"Small, incremental refactorings are safer than big rewrites.",
"Automated tests are essential for safe refactoring.",
"‘Code smells’ help detect deeper design problems.",
"Continuous refactoring prevents technical debt buildup.",
"Good names, small classes, low coupling, clear responsibilities.",
"Refactoring is a skill and a habit, not a one-time event."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{

"Large Class",

"Shotgun Surgery",
"Feature Envy",
"Data Clumps",
"Primitive Obsession",
"Long Parameter List",
"Divergent Change",
"Dead Code"

},

"Introduce Parameter Object",

"Encapsulate Field",
"Introduce Assertion",
"Rename Variable",
"Split Loop"
],
"when_it_applies": "Incremental improvements, redesigning parts of a system.",
"limitations": "Requires strong test coverage."
},
{
"name": "The Red–Green–Refactor Loop",

],

{

{
"title": "Clean Code",
"author": "Robert C. Martin (Uncle Bob)",
"category": "Software Engineering / Code Quality / Craftsmanship",
"tags": ["clean code", "software craftsmanship", "best practices", "engineering culture", "naming", "functions", "testing", "refactoring"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "Clean code is readable, simple, and maintainable. Good engineers write code for humans first and computers second — readable code is faster to develop, debug, and extend.",
"problem_statement": "Most codebases devolve into messy, complex systems that slow down teams. Dirty code increases bugs, onboarding time, and development cost, leading to technical debt that compounds.",
"target_audience": "Software engineers, tech leads, CTOs, engineering managers, architects.",
"promised_transformation": "A practical, principle-driven guide to writing elegant, readable, maintainable code — with standards that scale team performance and reduce long-term software costs.",
"key_ideas": [
"Clean code reads like well-written prose.",
"Meaningful names improve clarity dramatically.",
"Functions should be small and do one thing.",
"Comments are a failure to express intent — code should be self-documenting.",
"Objects and functions should follow single responsibility.",
"Error handling should be simple and consistent.",
"Tests must be clean too — otherwise they become liabilities.",
"Refactoring is continuous; cleanliness is a discipline.",
"Duplication is the root of many design problems."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "Characteristics of Clean Code",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Clean code is easy to read, easy to change, and easy to debug.",
"components": [
"Readable and expressive.",
"Minimal and simple.",
"Low coupling, high cohesion.",
"Meaningful naming.",
"Clear structure.",
"Avoids duplication.",
"Small, focused functions."
],
"when_it_applies": "All programming tasks — Greenfield, maintenance, refactoring.",
"limitations": "Requires team discipline and shared standards."
},
{
"name": "Meaningful Names",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Names should clearly communicate intent.",
"components": [
"Use descriptive nouns/verbs.",
"Avoid noise words.",
"Use domain language.",
"Follow conventions.",
"Prefer clarity over brevity."
],
"when_it_applies": "Naming variables, functions, classes, modules.",
"limitations": "Overly long names can reduce readability."
},
{
"name": "Functions Should Be Small",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Functions should do one thing — and one thing only.",
"components": [
"One level of abstraction.",
"Minimal parameters.",
"Clear side effects.",
"Consistent naming and purpose."
],
"when_it_applies": "Every code writing and refactoring scenario.",
"limitations": "Too-small functions can scatter logic."
},
{
"name": "Single Responsibility Principle (SRP)",
"type": "principle",
"description": "A class or function should have only one reason to change.",
"components": [
"Focused responsibility.",
"Separation of concerns.",
"Stable modules."
],
"when_it_applies": "Class design, API design, structuring modules.",
"limitations": "Requires experience to judge appropriate granularity."
},
{
"name": "The Clean Testing (TDD) Framework",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Tests must be clean — readable, fast, and independent.",
"components": [
"Readable names.",
"Small tests.",
"Fast execution.",
"Run frequently.",
"Avoid testing private implementation details."
],
"when_it_applies": "Test automation, CI/CD, refactoring safety.",
"limitations": "Bad tests can be harder to maintain than bad code."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Creating a Clean Code Culture",
"related_framework": "Characteristics of Clean Code",
"use_case": "Startup wants engineering velocity without chaos.",
"steps": [
"Draft Clean Code guidelines tailored to your stack.",
"Introduce code review checklists based on book principles.",
"Train engineers on naming, function design, and SRP.",
"Refactor new code continuously (‘Boy Scout Rule’).",
"Enforce linting and formatting tools.",
"Review test quality as rigorously as production code."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Naming functions like `generateInvoice()` instead of `genInv()`.",
"Refactoring onboarding logic into small reusable components."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Over-polishing code at the cost of delivery.",
"Inconsistent adoption across team.",
"Using clean code principles dogmatically."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Code review defects.",
"Time-to-onboard new engineers.",
"Bug regression rate.",
"Test coverage quality score (not %)."
]
},
{
"name": "Refactoring Dirty Code",
"related_framework": "Functions Should Be Small + SRP",
"use_case": "Legacy code slowing down new feature development.",
"steps": [
"Identify worst modules via friction logs.",
"Break large functions into small, named helpers.",
"Apply SRP to classes and modules.",
"Replace comments by clarifying code.",
"Remove duplication aggressively.",
"Improve naming clarity.",
"Add tests around critical logic before refactoring."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Breaking 600-line controller into route handlers.",
"Splitting user service into auth, profile, and permissions."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Refactoring without tests.",
"Changing functionality unintentionally.",
"Over-abstracting."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Lead time improvement.",
"Cyclomatic complexity reduction.",
"On-call incident reduction."
]
}
]
}

{
"title": "Financial Intelligence for Entrepreneurs",
"author": "Karen Berman, Joe Knight, John Case",
"category": "Finance / Entrepreneurship / Business Fundamentals",
"tags": ["financial literacy", "cash flow", "entrepreneur finance", "income statement", "balance sheet", "unit economics", "financial decision-making"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "Entrepreneurs must understand financial statements—not just accountants. True financial intelligence comes from knowing how the numbers are constructed, what drives them, and how they inform better business decisions.",
"problem_statement": "Most founders rely on intuition and misunderstand financial metrics. Without fluency in financial statements and cash flow, they make poor decisions that hurt profitability and long-term viability.",
"target_audience": "Founders, operators, small business owners, early-stage startup teams, managers.",
"promised_transformation": "A practical understanding of core financial statements, cash flow, key ratios, profitability levers, and how financial data influences strategic decisions.",
"key_ideas": [
"Financial intelligence = understanding how numbers are made + what they mean + how to use them.",
"Accounting involves assumptions—numbers are approximations, not absolute truth.",
"Cash is not profit; profit is not cash.",
"Income statement, balance sheet, and cash flow statement tell different stories.",
"Every financial metric is influenced by managerial choices.",
"Unit economics determine scalability.",
"Ratios help identify financial health and risks.",
"Numbers must always be interpreted in context."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "The Four Principles of Financial Intelligence",
"type": "framework",
"description": "A foundational model of how financially intelligent entrepreneurs think.",
"components": [
"1. Numbers are constructed through estimates and assumptions.",
"2. Understanding the art behind the numbers is essential.",
"3. Financials reflect the business model and management choices.",
"4. Context matters: compare trends, industry standards, and ratios."
],
"when_it_applies": "All financial decision-making.",
"limitations": "Requires hands-on reading of statements; cannot be outsourced blindly."
},
{
"name": "Three Core Financial Statements",
"type": "model",
"description": "A holistic view of business performance.",
"components": [
"Income Statement → shows profitability over time.",
"Balance Sheet → shows financial position at a moment in time.",
"Cash Flow Statement → shows how cash actually moves."
],
"when_it_applies": "Budgeting, forecasting, investor reporting.",
"limitations": "Must be interpreted together, not in isolation."
},
{
"name": "Profit vs Cash Framework",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Profit is theory; cash is reality. Businesses die when they run out of cash, not profit.",
"components": [
"Profit is influenced by accounting rules.",
"Cash flow depends on collections, payments, capital purchases, financing.",
"Working capital cycles impact liquidity."
],
"when_it_applies": "Startup runway, burn rate analysis, cash planning.",
"limitations": "Founders often misinterpret positive profit as healthy cash flow."
},
{
"name": "Unit Economics",
"type": "framework",
"description": "Measures profitability at the per-customer or per-unit level.",
"components": [
"CAC (Customer Acquisition Cost).",
"LTV (Lifetime Value).",
"Contribution Margin.",
"Payback Period."
],
"when_it_applies": "Business model viability, scaling decisions, investor communication.",
"limitations": "Requires accurate data and strong assumptions."
},
{
"name": "Key Ratios for Entrepreneurs",
"type": "model",
"description": "Ratios reveal the financial health and operational efficiency of the business.",
"components": [
"Gross Margin.",
"Operating Margin.",
"Current Ratio.",
"Quick Ratio.",
"Debt-to-Equity.",
"Inventory Turnover.",
"DSO (Days Sales Outstanding).",
"Burn Rate & Runway."
],
"when_it_applies": "Operational diagnostics, investor updates, board reporting.",
"limitations": "Ratios must be interpreted over time, not individually."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Building a Financial Dashboard for a Startup",
"related_framework": "Three Core Financial Statements + Key Ratios",
"use_case": "Founder needs clarity on financial health and runway.",
"steps": [
"Create monthly P&L, balance sheet, and cash flow statements.",
"Track revenue, gross margin, operating expenses, and net profit.",
"Add working capital indicators: AR days, AP days, inventory.",
"Calculate burn rate and runway from cash flow.",
"Visualize trends (3–6 month rolling average).",
"Conduct variance analysis vs forecast.",
"Review as a monthly founder ritual."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"SaaS dashboard including MRR, churn, CAC, LTV.",
"D2C dashboard tracking inventory turnover and contribution margin."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Tracking too many metrics.",
"Ignoring cash flow warning signs.",
"Not updating data regularly."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Burn rate.",
"Runway.",
"Gross margin trend.",
"Cash conversion cycle.",
"Contribution margin."
]
},
{
"name": "Creating a Cash Flow Management System",
"related_framework": "Profit vs Cash Framework",
"use_case": "Founder wants to avoid running out of money despite showing profit on paper.",
"steps": [
"Forecast monthly cash inflows/outflows for 12 months.",
"Identify major cash buckets (Opex, Capex, payroll, debt).",
"Improve working capital: negotiate terms, accelerate collections.",
"Build a 13-week short-term cash forecast.",
"Monitor actuals vs forecast weekly.",
"Build a minimum cash reserve policy."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Marketplace releasing funds to sellers on 7-day cycles.",
"SaaS with annual prepaid subscriptions improving cash position."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Assuming revenue = cash.",
"Ignoring payment timelines.",
"Overestimating future cash inflows."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Net cash flow.",
"Cash burn.",
"Minimum cash reserve.",
"DSO, DPO."
]
}
]
}

{
"title": "The Personal MBA",

"Time to return.",
"Risk profile.",
"Effort required."

"Value = solving important problems.",
"Test pricing early.",

"Removing friction.",
"Positive & negative loops.",
"2nd-order consequences."

}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [

"Identify which part is weakest.",
"Define 1–2 KPIs per part.",
"Design small experiments to improve weak areas.",
"Automate or standardize value delivery.",
"Introduce financial dashboards that tie the 5 parts together."
],
"examples_for_startups": [

"Cash flow from operations."

"Score risk (low/med/high).",
"Score effort.",

"Issues must be identified and solved permanently.",
"Processes must be documented and followed by all.",

{
"title": "The Goal",
"author": "Eliyahu M. Goldratt",
"category": "Operations / Systems Thinking / Manufacturing / Constraints",
"tags": ["TOC", "theory of constraints", "bottlenecks", "flow", "systems thinking", "operations management"],

"layer_1_meta_summary": {
"core_thesis": "Every complex system has one critical constraint (bottleneck) that determines its output. Improving anything other than the bottleneck does not improve performance. Optimizing flow, not individual efficiency, is the path to operational excellence.",
"problem_statement": "Most organizations try to improve every part of the system equally, leading to local optimizations that do not improve overall throughput. Teams miss bottlenecks and fail to align efforts to the true constraint.",
"target_audience": "Founders, COOs, operations leaders, product teams, engineering managers.",
"promised_transformation": "A deep understanding of bottlenecks, throughput, and system flow — and a simple method (TOC) to identify and eliminate constraints to improve overall performance.",
"key_ideas": [
"Throughput of the system is limited by its bottleneck.",
"Local optimizations often hurt global performance.",
"Flow > Efficiency.",
"Five Focusing Steps provide a systematic way to improve throughput.",
"Statistical fluctuations + dependent events create variability.",
"Batch sizes, buffers, and work-in-progress must be controlled.",
"Continuous improvement requires constant constraint elevation."
]
},

"layer_2_concepts_frameworks": [
{
"name": "Theory of Constraints (TOC)",
"type": "framework",
"description": "A systems-thinking approach to identify the single most limiting factor in any system.",
"components": [
"Identify the constraint.",
"Exploit the constraint (maximize output without investment).",
"Subordinate everything to the constraint.",
"Elevate the constraint (increase capacity).",
"Repeat — a new constraint appears."
],
"when_it_applies": "Product teams, supply chain, engineering, project management, ops.",
"limitations": "Assumes one dominant constraint; some systems have multiple interlinked constraints."
},
{
"name": "Bottleneck Management",
"type": "model",
"description": "Managing the constrained resource effectively improves system throughput.",
"components": [
"Avoid downtime.",
"Focus skilled labor at bottleneck.",
"Reduce variability.",
"Prioritize bottleneck work.",
"Limit WIP upstream."
],
"when_it_applies": "Growth-stage operations, engineering throughput.",
"limitations": "Requires accurate constraint identification."
},
{
"name": "Flow Optimization Principles",
"type": "principle",
"description": "Flow — not individual efficiency — determines total output.",
"components": [
"Smaller batch sizes.",
"Lower WIP.",
"Balanced workloads.",
"Unblocked dependencies.",
"Predictable throughput."
],
"when_it_applies": "Startup delivery pipelines, manufacturing, sprints.",
"limitations": "Counterintuitive for teams stuck in traditional thinking."
},
{
"name": "Drum–Buffer–Rope",
"type": "framework",
"description": "A TOC scheduling method ensuring bottleneck dictates system pace.",
"components": [
"Drum → bottleneck sets pace.",
"Buffer → protects bottleneck from upstream variability.",
"Rope → controls release of new work."
],
"when_it_applies": "Manufacturing, engineering workflows, task boards.",
"limitations": "Requires discipline to maintain buffers and limits."
},
{
"name": "Throughput Accounting",
"type": "model",
"description": "Financial decision-making based on throughput rather than cost allocation.",
"components": [
"Throughput (T).",
"Investment (I).",
"Operating Expense (OE).",
"Focus on increasing T, not shrinking OE."
],
"when_it_applies": "Pricing, capacity planning.",
"limitations": "Not widely adopted by traditional accountants."
}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [
{
"name": "Applying TOC to a Startup Workflow",
"related_framework": "Theory of Constraints",
"use_case": "Founder wants to improve team throughput and reduce delays.",
"steps": [
"Write down full flow of value from start → finish.",
"Identify the real bottleneck (measure wait time + queue size).",
"Focus team energy on unblocking bottleneck.",
"Reduce WIP upstream.",
"Add buffer before bottleneck.",
"Automate or outsource non-bottleneck tasks.",
"Once bottleneck is elevated, a new one appears — repeat."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Engineering pipeline → bottleneck in QA slows releases.",
"Sales funnel → demo capacity is bottleneck."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Misidentifying the constraint.",
"Optimizing non-constraints.",
"Failing to repeat the cycle."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Throughput (units shipped per week).",
"WIP levels.",
"Cycle time.",
"Bottleneck utilization."
]
},
{
"name": "Implementing Drum–Buffer–Rope in Product Teams",
"related_framework": "Drum–Buffer–Rope",
"use_case": "Team wants fewer delays and better predictability.",
"steps": [
"Identify bottleneck work center (design, backend, QA).",
"Set Drum pace based on bottleneck capacity.",
"Add Buffer (time or tasks) before bottleneck.",
"Use Rope to limit new tasks entering system.",
"Track WIP daily.",
"Review bottleneck performance weekly."
],
"examples_for_startups": [
"Limiting engineering WIP to 3 per dev.",
"Adding design buffer so engineers never wait for mocks."
],
"failure_modes": [
"Allowing too much WIP.",
"Ignoring upstream variability.",
"Letting non-bottleneck teams dictate pace."
],
"metrics_to_track": [
"Lead time.",
"WIP variance.",
"Bottleneck idle time.",
"Throughput consistency."
]
}
]
}

{
"title": "Working Backwards",

"Leadership Principles guide all decisions.",
"Long-term thinking is a competitive advantage."

},

"name": "Six-Page Narrative Memos",

"Logical flow.",
"Customer-centric framing.",
"Supporting data.",
"Read silently together before meetings."

"limitations": "Choosing wrong inputs leads to wasted effort."

"Separate team resources.",
"Full accountability.",
"Fast decision cycles."

}
],

"layer_3_implementation_guides": [

"name": "Creating a PR/FAQ for a New Product",
"related_framework": "Working Backwards Process",
"use_case": "Founder wants clarity before building an MVP.",

"Describe customer problem with clarity.",
"Explain why existing solutions fail.",
"Write 10–20 FAQ questions (risks, constraints, objections).",
"Define success metrics upfront.",
"Review with leadership for alignment.",
"Refine → validate with customers → then build MVP."
],
"examples_for_startups": [

"D2C brand: press release focusing on sustainability + pricing."

"failure_modes": [

"metrics_to_track": [

"Time saved by avoiding wrong builds."
]
},
{
"name": "Implementing Input Metric Dashboards",

"use_case": "Founder wants a predictable, controllable growth system.",
"steps": [

"Work backwards to find controlling inputs (e.g., onboarding speed).",

"Set ownership for each input metric.",

"Iterate aggressively."

"examples_for_startups": [

"failure_modes": [

"Output metric correlation.",
"Weekly trending dashboard."
]
}
]
}
